PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Harold Young) took the chair at 2.30 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Bolkus, I present the following petition from 44 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that the Health Care Card System introduced on September 1st for low income, unemployed, pensioners and other beneficiaries discriminates against the unemployed by its exclusion of pharmaceutical, optical and other entitlements to unemployed people . This discrimination results in greater hardship and distress to the unemployed and their dependants, and reduces their access to essential health facilities by increasing the onerous burden of health charges on this group which can least afford it.
This discrimination is a further example of the government's harsh and insensitive treatment toward the unemployed and their families, and creates unnecessary divisions within Australian society.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should review the health care card system and extend the benefits for pharmaceutical, optical and other entitlements to the unemployed (in line with the recent recommendation of the Australian Medical Association).
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLAREN

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 19 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned Citizens of South Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the special privileges bestowed on the Deputy Prime Minister Mr Anthony M.P. and the Minister for Primary Industry Mr Nixon M.P.-

(1) That in 1964 a Liberal/Country Party Government granted Mr Anthony M.P. a Commonwealth Government Home Loan Mortgage of $17,964 for a period of 45 years at a fixed interest rate of 4.75% and that at 1.10.81 the amount of principal outstanding was $15,005.

(2) That in 1970 a Liberal/Country Party Government granted Mr Nixon M.P. a Commonwealth Government Home Loan Mortgage of $30,352 for a period of 45 years at a fixed interest rate of 6.25% and that at 1.10.81 the amount of principal outstanding was $28,404.

(3) Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government immediately extend these most generous terms to the many thousands of young couples in South Australia who are at present suffering undue hardship and financial embarrassment due to high interest rates.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the amount of income permitted to pensioners before the loss of 50c in each dollar of pension for each extra dollar of income has not changed since 1972 although the CPI has risen by 161% in that time;
That the amount of income permitted to pensioners before fringe benefits are disallowed has not altered since 1979 although the CPI has risen 20% in that time; and
That pensioners are people who, while employed, paid taxes and contributed to compulsory superannuation schemes.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should increase both the amount of income permitted to pensioners before disallowance of fringe benefits and the amount allowed before the amount of pension received is reduced, to a realistic level; and also link those cut-off points to the CPI.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Postal Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate of the Australian Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of New South Wales respectfully showeth: That the plan by the Australian Postal Commission to investigate the downgrading or closure of RAAF Richmond post office places in jeopardy the existing postal and mail services to our community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government will take immediate action to prevent the Australian Postal Commission taking any action to downgrade the postal and mail services of our community.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Quality of Television Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that some television stations throughout Australia are taking advantage of the absence of ratings surveys during the Christmas-New Year holiday season to broadcast inferior quality programs and innumerable repeats.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the government will undertake and publish the results of ratings surveys during holiday periods to encourage the broadcasting of quality TV programs at those times.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth concern over Plant Variety Rights (PVR) legislation. We agree that:
(1) PVR will aggravate the free exchange of genetic material for plant breeding .
(2) PVR will not enhance Australia's access to improved plant varieties developed overseas but will encourage the dumping of unsuitable varieties on the Australian market.
(3) PVR will restrict the public plant breeding program to basic research for exploitation by private enterprise and discourage breeding for disease and pest resistant varieties.
(4) PVR will lead to the domination of the seed industry by foreign interests not responsible to the Australian people.
(5) The proprietary rights granted by PVR will encourage the introduction of seed distribution and marketing monopolies and lead to seed price increases.
Your petitioners therefore pray that Parliament:
(1) refrains from enacting any legislation on PVR,
(2) calls for a public enquiry into the impact of existing overseas PVR schemes on the Australian seed industry and the international seed trade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Senate assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that by imposing a sales tax on newspapers, magazines and books the Government intends to tax not only essential educational materials, thus adding to the ever increasing cost of educating Australia's greatest natural resource-our children, but also the organs of free speech which ensure the survival of our democracy, as well as affecting the livelihood of Australian authors.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate will reject the proposed sales tax on books, magazines and newspapers.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of Australia, concerned about the high and increasing rate of divorce and family breakdown, convinced that the Family Law Act has weakened marriage by making divorce a trivial matter, the present Act paying scant regard to its own definition of marriage as a life-long union; and believing that the legal bond of marriage should be strengthened; humbly petition for the Family Law Act and the Marriage Act to be amended in order to:
(1) reject any moves towards divorce by post
(2) restore the former prohibition of marriages between close relatives by blood or marriage
(3) protect the rights and welfare of aggrieved partners of a marriage who are threatened with being divorced against their will
(4) ensure that in divorce judgments paramount attention be given to whatever course will best serve the welfare of dependent children of the marriage
(5) encourage counselling towards reconciliation
(6) restore objective tests to irretrievable breakdown of marriage in terms of: (i) intolerable behaviour; (ii) desertion for two years; (iii) separation for three years.
And we pray that you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our nation .

PETITION.TITLE: Patients' Medical Records
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: That we are gravely concerned by the invasion of privacy caused by Government agents seizing patients' medical records.
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should
Legislate to protect the private and confidential nature of medical records from scrutiny except on the express and informed consent of the patient or an order from a presiding judge.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate is of the opinion that, given the anomalies and inequities existing in the present age pension scheme and given that Australia has an aging population, the Government should implement, as a matter of urgency, a national portable contributory superannuation scheme of a type similar to that recommended in the majority report of the National Superannuation Committee of Inquiry in April 1976.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to a statement on 29 April last year by the honourable member for Kooyong, Mr Peacock , in a speech giving the reasons for his resignation from the Cabinet, and to the fact that he complained about the Prime Minister's establishment of a so- called co-ordination committee. Mr Peacock referred to the committee as 'a powerful new element of government' superimposed over other Cabinet committees and, in effect, over Cabinet itself. I ask: Does this committee comprise the leaders and deputy leaders of the Liberal Party and the National Country Party? Is its role to discuss the entire range of departmental and ministerial responsibilities? Is the committee still operating? Does it consult with other Cabinet Ministers? Is the Minister in agreement or otherwise with the opinion expressed by Mr Peacock that it crushes the Cabinet system and is outrageous to the parliamentary system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the practice in, I think, virtually all the democratic parliaments of the world that have Cabinet systems of government that within the Cabinet system there are a variety of committees and indeed a small committee for special purposes which normally consists of the more senior Ministers. It has been the practice of this Government to have such committees over the years. They vary from time to time. There is a co-ordination committee. It comprises the leaders and deputy leaders, including the Government Leader in the Senate. They are fully responsible to the full Cabinet. Matters of significance that would normally involve full Cabinet are referred to full Cabinet and a decision is made in full Cabinet. I would reject entirely any criticism of the arrangement. It is a normal function of government common, I believe, in virtually every parliament that has a Cabinet system.
—I wish to ask a supplementary question. Has any change to the system been made since the criticism was offered in April last year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not recollect any such change. Certainly no change has been made in response to the criticism as I understand it, but I will take the question on notice and seek any additional information that exists.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs to a Press article which appeared in one newspaper last Friday and which , I believe, accurately quoted the Minister for Foreign Affairs as having said that over the last four years there has been little change in apartheid in South Africa. When did the Minister for Foreign Affairs or any other Minister of the Government last visit South Africa with a view to establishing, first hand, the actual situation in that country? Has the Minister for Foreign Affairs in fact spoken personally to the South African Ambassador in an attempt to obtain that country's views?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am not aware of the statement by the Minister for Foreign Affairs with regard to the fact that there has been little change over the past four years in relation to apartheid in South Africa. I am not aware of the other details requested. I will refer them to the Minister for Foreign Affairs for his response.

—I preface my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate by reminding him that a large number of Army and civilian personnel were employed at various atomic weapons testing areas around Australia during the period when testing was taking place. I have been advised by one of the former employees that he was refused a life assurance policy because he had been employed at one of those sites. Can the Minister inform the Parliament whether all persons who were similarly employed have been refused cover by all insurance companies or does this apply to some insurance companies only?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Keeffe may know that I have authorised, as the Minister responsible, a total contact with all persons now living, whether civilians or military personnel, who were associated with atomic tests in the Maralinga, Emu and Monte Bello Island areas. I have authorised also an extensive test of the reasons for the deaths of those no longer alive. We have already completed a pilot study which indicates to us that we can go ahead with the extensive study. We believe that there were something like 15,000 Australians, from various Services as well as civilians, involved altogether. I think we have located the records of the best part of 10,000 of those. I say that as a preface to give Senator Keeffe some idea of the nature of the details we are seeking. We then seek information on where those individuals were located, their likelihood of exposure and the dosimeters that were worn or that should have been worn to show any radiation. We do this to gain some background upon which to work. We widely publicised this. We are getting a considerable amount of correspondence from the community apart from that relating to the pilot scheme. I have never heard of a refusal by an insurance company to grant a life assurance policy because a person has served in those areas. That is not to say that it has not happened, or that it has not been mentioned in responses to us. I will direct the question to my Department for attention to see whether we have had any such responses. If there are any such people in the community I earnestly urge them to come forward and let us know because we want to contact them all. We have a completely genuine desire to make a thorough test, to find out what we can. Perhaps Senator Keeffe will give me the details of that individual. In the generality I widen that request to others.

—I ask a supplementary question. It may help the Minister to know that that person served at Maralinga. He stated that information on his recent compensation application which has been filed with the appropriate body.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful for that because it is a significant matter. I will follow that up. Honourable senators should know that it is also possible for persons to make applications before the Commonwealth Employees Compensation Tribunal. Those applications are being heard. I hope that Senator Keeffe will give me that person's name privately so that I can look up the file.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. In the light of the deficiencies shown by the Price Waterhouse Associates Pty study into meat export controls, such as inadequate segregation of domestic and export meat, seals on cartons being broken during handling and the like, will the Minister give an assurance that recommendations by the Price Waterhouse group will be given more than lip service and that inspectors will be more solidly backed up by management in their policing of the new inspection procedures?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry issued a media release on 20 January about the matter raised by the honourable senator. At that time Mr Nixon indicated what action he was taking on the report and also made copies of the report available to the Press. He described the report as confirming that the general approach taken in introducing the new measures was the correct one and he said that the report confirmed generally the approach adopted by the Government on these matters. Much of the subsequent media coverage concentrated on what they saw as being deficiencies in the controls as implemented without providing the balance of citing corrective action which was taken as soon as problems were identified.

ANSWER.PARA: In all, the Department of Primary Industry has identified 60 separate recommendations or suggestions put forward in the report by Price Waterhouse. Many of those will need prior consultation with the industry and with the authorities of Australia's customer countries. On 20 January the Minister personally initiated consultations with the industry, and he met again with industry leaders earlier this month. He does not propose to pre-empt those consultations by commenting in the interim on the specifics in the report. But it is quite clear from the attitude which the Minister has adopted that he will pursue all those recommendations to ensure that Australia's meat exports are protected to the greatest extent possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Finance whether it is correct that the Government has held discussions with Australian banks on the question of deregulating interest rates generally and, in particular, housing interest rates . Is it correct that the banks have pressed the Government very firmly either to deregulate or to allow them to increase their rates, including home interest rates, substantially? Can the Minister give categorical assurances that the Government has not decided to take one of these two courses but to defer any action until after the Lowe by-election and the Victorian election and that interest rates, particularly housing interest rates, which are being artificially depressed now will not be increased within three months following the Victorian election on 3 April?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — There is considerable detail in the question asked by the Leader of the Australian Democrats. In general terms, I can say that the Government is giving consideration to matters related to housing. Of course, that implies that discussions are being held with a number of people. It is common knowledge that the Treasurer meets with the banks for discussions, but I am not in any position to deal with the details of the question. I am not in possession of the full details of any discussions that may be held by the Treasurer with organisations which directly concern his responsibility. Senator Chipp asked whether interest rates would be increased within three months of the Victorian election. I think that type of question is very hypothetical whether it relates to interest rates or anything else. However, I undertake to refer the matter urgently to the Treasurer and to seek a response from him. If I have any further information later, I will see that the Senate is advised.

—I am sorry if the Minister regarded the question as complicated. I ask a supplementary question in response to her answer, which will considerably simplify the matter. In the discussions which the Government has had with the banks, have the banks pressed for an increase in home interest rates? Has the Government said: 'No. Wait until after the Lowe by-election and the Victorian election'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have nothing further to add at this stage. I have not been present in discussions with the banks. At this stage I am not in a position on behalf of the Treasurer to deal with the detail of the question. I undertake to get as early a response as is possible.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. Has the Minister seen reports that the European Parliament has voted overwhelmingly to ban imports of seal products? Although the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has been reported to have described the trade in seal skins and products in Australia as minimal, in view of the public revulsion at the so-called harvesting of young harp and hooded seals in order to produce adornments and trinkets, will the Government promote a ban on the products as an indication that Australia regards the slaughter as barbaric and intolerable?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hill referred to Press reports about the European Parliament. Indeed, such a motion was carried in that Parliament. I understand that the resolution will now have to go back to the constituent countries for further action. The resolution passed by the European Parliament is not of itself binding or necessarily effective. In relation to what the Australian Government has done, I am advised that the Federal Government has taken a strong stand generally and has taken positive action in relation to the issue of the import and export of wildlife and wildlife products.

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised that the Government intends to introduce very shortly the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Imports and Exports) Bill which will strengthen existing controls on exports and imports of wildlife. The legislation is designed to control better the export of Australian native species and it would also extend coverage from existing Customs regulations to include animals and plant species added to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species which, as Senator Hill would know, was ratified by Australia in 1976. The legislation will also provide a mechanism for prohibiting the imports of animal products and wildlife even if the species involved are not actually endangered-if there are other reasons why they should be prohibited. The Government would be prepared to consider the banning of all seal products under this provision of the new Bill in the light of significant Australian public reaction to the current Canadian seal harvest. I understand that consultations on the legislation which I have described are in an advanced stage with the Northern Territory and the States.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Health read the report in this morning's Melbourne Age of the Victorian Health Minister Borthwick's comment on the golden staphylococcus epidemic? Did the Minister of Health in the Victorian Liberal Government state that $3m had been allocated in the last Budget for methicillin resistant staphylococcus aureus control measures but did he admit that his Government had not yet allocated the money to be included in approved hospital budgets? Will the Federal Government protect the people of Victoria and other Australians by urgently making funds available to the States to compensate hospitals for the high cost of measures to control MRSA and isolate infected patients? Will the Government allocate funds to research and develop a new drug to fight the antibiotic resistant golden staph germ?

—Without having read the Age newspaper this morning, I cannot pick up the details or confirm for the honourable senator whether a Minister said this or said that or made certain comments. It is quite clear though that the honourable senator seems to misunderstand the problem of resistant staphylococci and what that means in hospitals. Misunderstanding the problem, he is suggesting what are really quite facile and inappropriate solutions. The golden staph has been around for many years. When I was a medical student in the late 1950s it was a problem then and people were dying from golden staph infection. The problem is not one that will be solved by money alone. To put it in terms of a solution which can be found by opening the money coffers and pouring money in is to misstate and to misrepresent the problem. It is a problem which goes to the capacity of organisms to change their nature and resistance. This is neither a recent problem nor a problem which has become markedly worse. It is a problem which relates to the way we use antibiotics and to cross-infection in hospitals. I know Mr Borthwick would be approaching this matter with sensitivity, care and responsibility. Money alone will not be appropriate to solve the problem.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. This week there has been strong criticism of the industrial disruption and resultant high costs within the shipping and waterfront industries by the President of the Tasmanian Farmers and Graziers Association, Mr Allwright. Is it a fact that the proliferation of unions is a major cause of the significant disruption? If it costs half as much to get containers from Melbourne to Rotterdam as it does to get them from Tasmania to Melbourne, what chance do Australian primary producers and manufacturers have of competing with overseas imports? Will the Minister have the costs of compulsory use of Australian shipping for our coastal trade examined, as we are told by the Germans that our port loading costs are four times higher than those which apply anywhere else in the world?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the second time over recent weeks that Senator Archer has raised this very vexed matter in the Senate. In my previous answer to him I stressed the concern of the Government and of the Minister for Industrial Relations at the continued disruption on the waterfront. I pointed out also that the matter had been raised at the Premiers Conference and the State Labour Ministers Conference and that discussions are to be held with employers and unions in the waterfront and maritime areas. At the State Labour Ministers Conference all Ministers agreed to examine their respective industrial jurisdictions to see what further steps, if any, might be taken to facilitate the process of settling demarcation disputes. In other words, the Ministers from all States were expressing concern about the central issue in the question which has been raised by Senator Archer this afternoon.

ANSWER.PARA: Those discussions are now being arranged. It is my hope and the hope of the Minister that they will help to improve the industrial relations climate in these industries. My colleague, Mr Viner, is examining ways of strengthening the role of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to resolve demarcation disputes. How that can be achieved needs very careful thought, but the process which has developed will place emphasis on conciliation and arbitration being exploited to the fullest extent possible. The Government has also foreshadowed that legislation to enable the creation of industry unions will be introduced to the Parliament during these sittings. That legislation will provide the means for a single waterfront union to represent the interests of all waterfront employees should they so desire and will go a long way towards overcoming the level of industrial disruption in the area.

Senator Archer raised some very specific questions about cost and compared the cost of getting containers from Melbourne to Rotterdam with the cost of getting them from Tasmania to Melbourne. He referred to the difficulty that that poses for Australian primary producers and manufacturers when they are competing with overseas imports. It is axiomatic that an efficient system of transport, including efficiency on the waterfront and in the shipping industry, is central to the welfare of Australia's primary producers and manufacturers and all exporters. The extent to which our use of Australian shipping is counterproductive is a matter which needs careful examination.

Senator Archer referred to the fact that our port loading costs are four times higher than anywhere else in the world. Without having the detail before me I think that figure would probably apply whether we were using overseas shipping or coastal shipping. But within the context of a concern for our exporters the Commonwealth is also concerned to try to encourage Australian shipping. The present Minister for Transport, Mr Hunt, has certainly directed his attention to the possibility of extending Australian involvement in shipping. I think all Australians-indeed all honourable senators-would support that in principle. The difficulty for us as a government and for Australia as a country is that unless the trade unions involved are a co-operative part of that process of encouraging participation the fears which were expressed in Senator Archer's question are valid and certainly will tell against any effort to maintain even existing Australian involvement in that area let alone be the basis of some expansion.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Social Security, relates to a number of rumours that have been circulating in regard to payments made under the supporting parents legislation. I ask the Minister: Have any changes been proposed or made to payments being made under the 1973 supporting parents legislation? I ask also: Have any changes been made to the system of counter cheques being paid in cases of emergency to those people who can gain a benefit under that legislation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The only change that I am aware of that has been introduced by this Government with respect to the Act to which the honourable senator referred in his question is that during the life of this Government and during the term of office of Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, my predecessor as Minister for Social Security, the benefit was extended to supporting parents as against supporting mothers. The benefit was made available to those fathers in the difficult position of trying alone to look after small children. So although the relative numbers are small, a significant group of Australians dealing with children under conditions of hardship has received additional assistance to that which was originally available under the 1973 legislation.

ANSWER.PARA: No doubt the question and the rumours referred to in the question arise out of the concern which has been expressed in a number of quarters about the very considerable expansion of the number of people receiving the supporting parent's benefit. That expansion would appear to be very largely related to the large number of broken marriages. The major proportion of supporting parents are the victims-if 'victims' is the correct description-of broken marriages. There has been a significant change. It is an area of increasing expenditure and it is understandable therefore that there should be expressions of interest both within political parties and in the general community. A number of things which are relevant to that situation are under consideration. A recommendation of a parliamentary committee which relates to the question of the collection of maintenance is being examined by the Attorney-General and me and by our respective departments. That does not amount to any suggestion that there be a restriction on the benefit but goes to provisions of the Family Law Act which relate payments of maintenance or orders for the payment of maintenance to the availability of social security benefits.

Another aspect which is no more than a very distant gleam in someone's eye-if it is a gleam in anyone's eye-is the New Zealand experiment in this area. The New Zealand Government has introduced a new system of having a departmental assessment of the contribution by the non-supporting parent. That was described to a couple of meetings of the Council of Social Welfare Ministers by the attending New Zealand Minister. It is a matter of some interest. It is a very new scheme in New Zealand. It certainly has teething problems and all Australian Ministers are watching that development with interest. For the rest, there are no proposals in train which would change conditions of that benefit. In this area, as in other areas, I would welcome some public discussion as long as it is sensible and constructive. I think the fact that that area is probably the largest growth area in the social security system reflects some changes in Australian society which may not be altogether beneficial. I think we ought to be looking at the extent to which the benefit system is performing the function that we would want. It is quite clear that this Government, like the previous Government, is concerned to see that those Australians who are, for the reason that they have the care of children, unable to provide support for themselves should be assisted by their fellow Australian taxpayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, relates to program selection for ethnic television. Has the Minister received complaints from ethnic groups about some programs, especially some feature films? Is he aware that one such group in New South Wales alleges the development of an avalanche of communist propaganda on Channel O-28, Sydney?
—Who is that-Lajovic's mate?
—I ask whether ethnic groups are represented in the program decision making process and whether programs are monitored by the Commonwealth.
—This is 1982, not 1952.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a little distressing that the Opposition should react so badly to any suggestion that there could be something wrong with programs on Channel 0-28 being used for communist propaganda. I hope that all honourable senators want to see the programs not used for propaganda by anyone for any purpose. It is correct that complaints are received from time to time about programs broadcast on Channel 0-28, and programs on other channels, including complaints about feature films. The Minister receives complaints from time to time.

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised that there were some recent complaints from the Hungarian community in Sydney about the telecasting of a film called Hungarian Rhapsody. I do not know the content of that film but, if Senator Walters is correct and the film contains communist propaganda, I would think that was undesirable. The Special Broadcasting Service is aware of the complaints. It has pointed out that of six Hungarian films screened in the past 15 months only two have been the subject of criticism from some members of the Hungarian community. The other four have attracted no criticism.

Ethnic groups are not represented in the program decision-making process at this stage. However, the Minister proposes to announce in due course membership of the SBS National Advisory Council to achieve this purpose. The SBS is an independent statutory authority and its programs are not monitored by the Commonwealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that the document quoted from by the Minister be tabled.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN BROADCASTING COMMISSION: 'A TOWN CALLED ROXBY'

TALK.START.PARA: —My question also is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. I was interested to hear his comment that he is concerned that programming is not used as a propaganda system. Is the Minister aware that the Australian Broadcasting Commission intends to screen, as part of its Sunday night program Weekend Magazine, a film made and sponsored wholly by the Western Mining Corporation Ltd? Is the Minister further aware that this film , A Town Called Roxby, presents a very biased view of a subject, that subject being the mining of the copper-uranium deposit at Olympic Dam in South Australia , a subject upon which the people of South Australia are very evenly divided?
—No, they are overwhelmingly in favour of it.
—They are opposed to it. It is Liberal propaganda that the ABC is going to show.

—I appreciate the assistance of my colleagues. Is it a fact that the Commission is being forced to adopt such politically biased programming because of financial restraints imposed on it by the Fraser Government? Does the Minister think that such biased presentations of films harm the credibility of the ABC?

—I understand that, like the Special Broadcasting Service, the Australian Broadcasting Commission has control over its own programming content. I do not know whether Weekend Magazine will screen the program referred to by Senator Bolkus, nor do I know whether that film was produced by the Western Mining Corporation Ltd, nor yet do I know whether Senator Bolkus is correct or totally incorrect when he asserts that that film is in some way a propaganda exercise. I can say to the honourable senator that it is quite incorrect and improper to suggest that the ABC's programming is being determined by any financial restraints. Let me make one other point. The criticism I receive from ethnic communities relates not only to the content of some of the films shown but also to their concern that those of us who do not speak the particular foreign language have no way of knowing what is coming over. The ABC at least operates in the major language in the culture. Most of us can watch it and form our own views on anything that is screened.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NORTHERN SAMAR INTEGRATED RURAL DEVELOPMENT PROJECT

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and it concerns the scrutiny of Australian aid projects. Is the Minister aware that criticisms have been levelled at the Northern Samar Integrated Rural Development Project which claim that rather than benefiting the poor the project is in fact further contributing to the poverty of the area? What controls are imposed on Australian aid to ensure that the objectives of any project are being met and that money is not being misspent?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs is aware of letters in the Press which were critical of Australia's involvement in the Northern Samar region. There were reports of violence in this area. A number of those contained factual errors and presented a false impression of the Australian Government's objectives in undertaking development assistance programs in that region. The sole objective of Australia's commitment is to assist with the development of Northern Samar. It is one of several areas in the Philippines that are in great need of development assistance. Unfortunately, social tensions, political problems and insurgency activities are generally greatest in areas which are most depressed and economically deprived. The part of the question which related to the steps that are taken to ensure that money and funds are spent in the most useful way and that we have the accountability that we all require ought to be referred to the Minister for Foreign Affairs to see what response he wishes to make. I draw attention to the fact that some errors were made in the Press statements with regard to the particular area that is the subject of the question.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. In the interests of both freedom of information and curbing possible excesses in the administration of police phone tapping and audio-surveillance powers, will the Government make available all or any part of the Hemmingway reports on phone tapping and listening device procedures made to the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police, Sir Colin Woods, in July and August last year? What plans does it have to ensure such reporting in future?

—The matter, although it concerns an Act of which I have the administration, raises questions which particularly concern the administration of the Australian Federal Police, for which I am not responsible. The matter will need to be discussed by me with the Minister for Administrative Services. I have some knowledge of the report to which Senator Evans refers, but I am not well acquainted with it. I refer the Minister to the endorsement by the Standing Committee of further consultation and investigation by a working party comprising the Department of Primary Industry, the Northern Territory and Queensland to determine which South East Asian countries will accept meat from abattoirs of this standard and the level of support for the concept from the meat industry. —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Government given consideration to how it intends to prevent income tax being paid by pensioners when the May consumer price index increase in the pension, together with the additional income that pensioners may receive, will raise the income of many pensioners above the tax threshold?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I understand that until a later rise in pension payments there will be no problem with regard to those who currently are not required to pay income tax. At the time that will be a matter for consideration by the Government. The threshold at which tax first becomes payable is a matter that constantly is reviewed. When the Government is preparing a Budget or at any other appropriate time it can give consideration to what measures should be taken. In the broad, this is a matter of policy. It is a matter that does not escape our attention. It is not one on which I would wish to make any announcement at present. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful to Senator Grimes for asking the question because it helps me to bring to the Senate's attention the part of my answer to the question last week which he did not quote. I said that I was looking forward to receiving comments from Mr Evans if he disagreed with my assumption. The point about that is that that comment has now come forward. —It is a pity to mislead the Senate to do it. There are other ways.

—I was not misleading the Senate at all. I will explain that in a moment. The point is that there were three drafts of this document, as far as I understand the position. ANSWER.PARA: I mentioned last week that I felt that all interest in the matter had stalled as a result of Senator Grimes having tabled the second draft of that document about a year ago. TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question. Am I to understand that the Minister's reply last week, when on two occasions he stated that that document- the third draft, as he calls it-was the property of Mr Evans, was just a means of provoking Mr Evans into denying it? —No, that is not the position at all. What I was seeking to do was to make it clear to Mr Evans, and to all other interested persons, that I was trying to clear the air on this matter altogether by laying down the document even though I was unsure as to whether I really had a right to do so.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: HEALTH INSURANCE FOR AUSTRALIAN VISITORS TO THE UNITED KINGDOM

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. By way of preface, I refer to the decision of the British Government to terminate its concession for overseas visitors to have their hospital costs covered should they suffer illness in Britain. I now put to the Minister: In view of the fact that most nations have knock for knock arrangements to meet this situation, is it true that citizens of Australia and the United States, which countries lack a national health scheme and are in bondage to private schemes, will not have cover after September should they have the misfortune to be ill in Britain and to enter a British hospital?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that a series of arrangements is in existence between the United Kingdom and Australia under which United Kingdom visitors to Australia receive the following health benefits: Nursing home benefits, domiciliary nursing care benefits and pharmaceutical benefits under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. It is only when it comes to private medical services or hospital services that they would not be covered unless they had private health insurance. Public hospital in-patient and out-patient services are matters for the State governments to determine. If any of them want to provide United Kingdom visitors with services without charge, that is a matter entirely for them to decide. They now receive the money which was previously administered by the Commonwealth and they can decide how it is to be used.

ANSWER.PARA: The United Kingdom government will continue to provide Australian visitors with cover for emergency health services. The provision of non-urgent health services free of cost is a subject of continuing discussion between the United Kingdom and Australian governments. The Minister for Health, in his recent visit to England, had discussions on this matter with the United Kingdom Minister, Dr Vaughan.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question. Should I interpret the middle of the Minister's response to mean that, if the various Premiers want to, they can empower their agents-general to negotiate on behalf of the States to overcome the problem in this grey area? Is that what the Minister is saying?

—My advice is that the arrangements for the States in the operation of their hospital services are entirely a matter for the States to determine. They can make arrangements to cover visitors to Australia if they so wish and if they are prepared to use the money which has been given to them as a block grant for that purpose.

ANSWER.PARA: As far as the other matter is concerned, I still have to take to the Government the results of the work I have been doing with respect to section 47 of the social security legislation. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. It is prompted by the editorial assertion on the Australian Broadcasting Commission news yesterday that the Labor by-election victories last Saturday caused yesterday's four- point fall in the stock exchange all ordinaries index. Will the Minister ask the oracles in ABC news what caused the all ordinaries index to fall 280 points in the 14 months prior to yesterday?
—Whoever else should answer that question, it is not a question for ABC officers to answer.

—I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to the latest unemployment figures which show that a record 482,600 Australians, or 7 per cent of the work force, are now unemployed. Is this tragedy not a direct result of the 1981-82 Howard Budget, which was deliberately aimed at slowing down the rate of growth of the Australian economy? Can the Minister tell the Senate what level we can expect unemployment to reach before the Government does the same as Mrs Thatcher in Britain and changes the course of its restrictive economic policies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The 1981-82 Budget was designed to assist with investment confidence and activity. I think any of the measurements that we can use will show that that has occurred. Investment activity has been strong. We all regret the unemployment figures that were released recently. A number of factors do need to be taken into account. I think, in particular, we are all anxiously awaiting the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission's response to the matters before it because if we are to see improved employment opportunities we need to recognise that interest rates, wage demands and other things are very important indeed in relation to providing the confidence that will enable people to go ahead and expand the employment opportunities in this country. I think we should note the increase that there has been in employment at the same time as regretting the unemployment figures that are before us.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not seek to respond to the latter part of the question. Employment in this country is of vital importance. I hope that we will all see many ways in which we are able to assist that. In particular, I hope that we can see that wage demands that are made by the people who are working make it very difficult indeed for people who have no employment prospects. In those terms, we hope that there is some restraint in wage demands and wage conditions which make it difficult for people to employ their capital profitably and to provide the expansion in employment that we all wish to see.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Attorney-General considered the concern expressed by Mr Collins, Leader of the Opposition in the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly, which was echoed in the Senate by Senator Evans, that the Evidence Amendment Bill introduced by the Attorney-General of the Northern Territory, Mr Everingham, will restrict the power of the Aboriginal Land Commissioner in conducting his inquiries, particularly into the Kenbi land claim? Does the Commonwealth Government intend to take any action in regard to the matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that last Thursday Senator Robertson asked me a question about the Evidence Amendment Bill that had been introduced by Mr Everingham that day in the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly. At that stage I was not aware of what had occurred. Later in the day I became aware of the matter. I received a telex from Mr Collins, the Leader of the Opposition in the Northern Territory. I think that message was probably received by a number of senators. Senator Evans, in the adjournment debate in the Senate on Thursday evening, lent his support to the concern expressed. I have considered the matters raised by Mr Collins, Senator Evans and Senator Robertson. Other senators have also expressed concern to me, in particular Senator Baume, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. The position is that I do not believe that there is any need for this Parliament to take any action to amend or clarify the powers under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act as a result of the action that has been taken in the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly, even assuming that that becomes law .

ANSWER.PARA: There is a well established principle of law which was first enunciated in the High Court of Australia as far back as 1929 in the case of the Federal Capital Commission and Laristan Building and Investment Co. Pty Ltd. Under that rule of law legislation of a territory, such as the Northern Territory still is, cannot detract from the operations of the provisions of a Commonwealth statute. The Commissioner's powers to require evidence are stated in fairly wide terms in section 54 of the Aboriginal Lands Rights (Northern Territory) Act. As far as I am aware, he has successfully operated under that provision without difficulty. Therefore, the mere passage of legislation by the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly, which may be thought to detract from the power of the Commissioner to seek evidence of the kind covered by the Bill, would offend the principle of the High Court case which I mentioned. It would not have any effect on the existing powers of the Aboriginal Land Commissioner.
