DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Button proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's neglect of the people of rural and provincial Australia.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —One Australian in three lives in rural and provincial areas of Australia. Those areas earn almost a half of our export income and constitute a key component in our national life. I think it is important in considering policies in relation to those areas to realise that not all Australians who live outside metropolitan areas live on farms; they live in small towns and in large provincial cities. They have always been, with various degrees of assessment, a disadvantaged group, particularly disadvantaged in relation to the delivery of government services. I believe that is something which ought to be acknowledged by all political parties, especially the National Country Party, which has pretended to safeguard country interests- the real interests safeguarded by the Country Party being, of course, sectional ones. For the last 20 years at least those interests have been only tenuously connected with country areas-that Party's interest principally being in mining companies, mostly foreign. There is little doubt about who bankrolls the Country Party; one has only to look at the favours that have been done for the mining industry over many years.

SPEECH.PARA: Briefly, there are three areas that need attention in rural and provincial Australia from the point of view of government. The first is the need for detailed understanding of the level of disadvantage which country people suffer as compared with people in the cities. Secondly, I think it is important to understand the withdrawal of government or public services from country people which has taken place over the last six years. Thirdly, it is important to understand the ad hoc way in which policies of assistance for non-metropolitan areas have been formulated and the failure of the Government, or governments, to come to grips with decentralisation issues in a time of significant movements of population within Australia.

What becomes clear in any examination of rural and provincial Australia is the lack of real knowledge of the question of social disadvantage. It is quite clear that there are shortcomings in the delivery of basic services such as health, education housing, transport and communications. These services affect the general quality of life and they are frequently in turn affected by the great distances involved in non-metropolitan Australia. Other disadvantages such as a lack of employment opportunities and deficiencies in social, cultural and sporting facilities stem from the dispersed nature of country population. In country areas it costs more money to provide such services for the people than it does in the cities. The last six years of cost cutting-I do not want to enter into this debate today as it is an issue which we debate often enough here-often aimlessly and carried out without constructive forethought has had the effect of further eroding the delivery of basic services in the country. The effect of these policies since 1975 can be detailed or referred to briefly under various headings. The first is reduced funds for roads. Despite higher costs, real funding for roads has been substantially reduced. There is agreement about that, from the secretaries of nearly every shire council in Australia to the Premier of Queensland, Mr Joh Bjelke-Petersen, who made a statement about it as recently as last Saturday. The National Farmers Federation raised this matter in its publication 'Farm Focus: The 80s' when it said:
Considerable upgrading is necessary if the road system is to meet the needs of the 80s . . .
It went on to deal with that issue at some length.

The second manifestation of disadvantage is in petrol prices. According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, rural or provincial households spend nearly 10 per cent of their income on liquid fuel compared with 3 per cent spent by Australians living in metropolitan households. Considerations of petrol prices for country areas, freight equalisation and so on flow from that situation. Another area concerns natural gas, the acquisition of which gives country communities a greater chance to compete for new industry with coastal cities. I was talking not so long ago to the Mayor of Wagga Wagga about this very problem. He pointed out the range of new industries which the Council has been able to attract to that city because of the provision of natural gas. In my State of Victoria, programs to provide natural gas to towns such as Stawell and Ararat have been talked about for a long time but have not been implemented. The same comment can be made about the New South Wales towns of Lithgow, Bathurst and Orange. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) specifically promised that natural gas would be provided to those cities by pipeline, and they are still waiting some several years after that promise was made.

A range of other issues abound in relation to the country. The effects of housing policies are more dramatic in country areas than perhaps they are in the cities. The Victorian Government, if I might again use my home State as an example, has compounded this problem in that approvals for housing have reached their lowest level since 1962. Victorian building societies are reporting a dramatic loss of funds, investors and borrowers. That points to poor growth in the cities and further stagnation in the country areas where the demand for public housing and low cost housing traditionally has been greater.

I mention those as a few of the problems that arise from a lack of a national approach to regional Australia. Let me be more specific for a minute and refer to three provincial cities with which I personally am more familiar. The first of those three cities is, of course, Bendigo. I do not want to go at great length into a topic which has been discussed here recently. As revealed by the Langley inquiry in 1979 more than 30 per cent of under 24-year-olds were out of work in Bendigo at that time. The average rate of unemployment in that city then was 10 per cent. There are now no Commonwealth Employment Service figures for country towns because the Government has abolished CES figures for employment in country towns. But there is no doubt from welfare agencies in Bendigo that the situation has deteriorated since the Langley survey. Similarly, one can look at Bendigo's industry with the depressed situation of the meat works resulting in further unemployment and, more particularly, the repercussions of the Government 's decision about the Bendigo Ordnance Factory which has enormous social implications for that city in terms of employment and wealth generation to the local economy. I suppose that that is just one example of a provincial town in which that sort of situation applies.

If one looks at the city of Geelong similar indicators are available. In the last quarter of last year the value of new commercial buildings under construction was 53 per cent down on the previous year. Building society loans were down by 25 per cent and new car registrations were down by 14.2 per cent- all, in a sense, meaningless figures unless one relates them to similar figures in the major cities where the statistics are far less dramatic than they are in country towns of this type.

If one looks at the city of Ballarat, it is now not possible to find out the level of unemployment, particularly among young people in that town, in the way in which it used to be possible as the razor gang stopped the publication of CES figures. But in March last year-the last month before the razor gang report was presented-the unemployment rate in Ballarat was 9.5 per cent. Evidence from employers, civic authorities and welfare agencies shows that it is now well over 10 per cent. The figure for youth unemployment is said to be well over 20 per cent. Just this morning the Ballarat Courier contained a report that bankruptcies in small business over the past six months have risen very sharply. The blame for these bankruptcies has included, notably, high interest rates and a major recession in the local building industry of that town. Similarly, big employers in that city have been affected by recession, particularly engineering firms and, again, the local abattoirs.

All these statistics paint a general picture of the impact of wider economic policies having graver effects on provincial communities than they do on the larger metropolitan areas of Australia. Similarly, let me refer the education policies which have been followed by perhaps a series of governments. I refer to the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme and the fact that the availability of education in a wide range of subject choices is much less in provincial towns than in the cities. A lot of work falls on local organisations in trying to redress that situation.

There have been ad hoc and somewhat abortive efforts over the years to recognise this problem and grapple with it. The Fraser Government made an attempt to recognise the peculiar economic problems of provincial towns in 1977. In that year it established the Commonwealth Government Decentralisation Development Program. Funding of urban and regional development, by the way, has declined in real terms by 90 per cent since the Fraser Government came to office , but in 1977 there was this effort with the establishment of a Decentralisation Advisory Board which was designed to implement this program in specific recognition of rural disadvantage, particularly in relation to the provincial economies of the larger rural cities.

The Decentralisation Advisory Board spent $36m during its life. The sum of $10. 5m was allocated in the last year of its existence-1980-81. It was not able to spend most of that allocation because in April 1981 it was disbanded by the razor gang accompanied by the statement that decentralisation and regional development was more properly a matter for State governments than the Federal Government. If that is the view, I do not know why it was not held in 1977. There was then a recognition by the national Government of the importance of the problem and of the fact that national government had a contribution to make towards its solution. It is estimated that the Decentralisation Advisory Board was responsible for the creation of nearly 10,000 jobs in provincial and rural Australia-3,200 of them directly and the rest as a result of the creation of those jobs in various industries. This was a small initiative in terms of cost- the Board was a body which provided a catalyst rather than on-going financial assistance-but it has been completely wiped out. I think this is a significant retreat in terms of national government responsibilities for people who live in the non-metropolitan areas.

The problems of rural and provincial Australia seem to get worse. The principal reasons are: Firstly, the decline in the prosperity of manufacturing industry and its effects on the manufacturing bases of regions; and, secondly, the rapid expansion in a few regions due to large scale mining development which has meant a sharp decline in established provincial areas and a too-rapid increase in resource development areas such as sections of Queensland, the La Trobe Valley and areas in Western Australia. The result is that people in older established provincial areas are being made increasingly jobless and unable to move because of the buyers' market in houses. The impact of the so-called resources boom, whether or not it exists-there is some doubt about that-has resulted in tremendous pressures for the provision of infrastructure when new population centres are arising outside the major cities.

The result in social welfare terms has been something of a planning disaster with the development of a so-called caravan culture which places tremendous pressure on welfare agencies, creates family tensions and causes disruptions in those new and developing areas. Thirdly, further job losses are occurring in service industries in regional areas resulting from technological change and centralisation of the operations of many companies. Fourthly, there has been a sharp increase in the rate of growth of Australia's population. That is important in stressing the necessity for a national government response to these issues rather than, as the Government advocated in April last year, leaving the matter to State governments. Even if the Commonwealth does not pay for it, there should be a national strategy in relation to population movements in the non- metropolitan areas.

I shall suggest, in conclusion, what might be done in relation to some of these areas if government is looking forward into the medium and long term future about the very real problem which exists in these areas to which I have referred . Firstly, I believe top priority needs to be given to a detailed examination of what is in fact happening in rural and provincial Australia. We need to know what disadvantages there are in regard to basic services and the quality of life . There are a number of quite clearly apparent indicators but what they mean in terms of a variety of regions in Australia needs further assessment. Secondly, there needs to be consideration of how decentralisation of population can be put on a realistic footing, taking into account the successes and failures of early decentralisation initiatives. Thirdly, we need to consider how we could give impetus, perhaps in a not very costly way, to the effort of the local communities in strengthening their industrial bases. The experiment with the Decentralisation Advisory Board seems to have been worthwhile in that regard. Fourthly, there needs to be a strategy to consider how regional communities can be discouraged from competing needlessly with each other for industry and resource development. Fifthly, we need to consider strategies for encouraging and implementing regional planning so that local communities can approach development in an ordinary way.

I do not say this on a particularly partisan basis, but I think there is a need for an inquiry which would be wide-ranging and which would put pressure on Federal governments of either political persuasion to take some positive action in terms of long term strategy to redress the problems of rural and provincial Australia. Unless we do this we will go on blindly trying with ad hoc methods to identify the real needs in the non-metropolitan regions and we will continue to make decisions which are merely band-aid remedies or, worse, are taken for short term political gains. Of course, a number of things can be done straight away. We could re-establish at the national level at least a co-ordinating program to assist and rationalise decentralisation programs. Secondly, the Decentralisation Advisory Board showed us how that could be done in a modest way and yet generate employment which is of crucial importance in the social fabric of rural communities. Thirdly, we can ensure a fairer distribution of funds for such basic services as roads and education. Finally, we might better manage the economy so that farmers, small businessmen, and ordinary households in rural and provincial areas can look to the future of their communities with a confidence that today is being undermined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The closing words of the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Button) are probably the words on which we are most likely to agree. He drew attention to the importance of economic management to the people he was addressing in his matter of public importance today. I agree that the most significant requirement for rural and provincial centres and for the people who live in rural and provincial centres is that there should be a sound economic base from which they can operate. One of the things which is of most significance about the rural and provincial areas of Australia is one of the points made by Senator Button early in his speech; they produce about half the export income of this country. It is a fact that those rural and regional areas depend very greatly upon our economic health, upon the direct production of wealth, often for export, and they suffer if the economy is not running well.

SPEECH.PARA: One can think of many rural and provincial centres which rely on our great traditional rural industries such as grain, livestock and sugar. We know of many which rely on our great metal industries such as iron, gold and coal and other energy projects. We know that others rely upon an active tourist industry. It is quite evident that if we are concerned about the health and welfare of those people one of our primary concerns has to be the economic situation as it affects those communities.

It is always attractive to talk in terms of a plan, an examination and an investigation which will disclose what is required and which will lead to pressure on government to take appropriate action to remedy the ills which exist . Of course, there are ills and problems in all sections of the Australian community which can be and need to be addressed. It is desirable for the Senate to remind itself that the sort of approach so apparently rational and so apparently concerned with real problems which was adopted by the then Government in 1972-75 did not necessarily produce the clear results which one might have hoped when the course was first established. In examining the way we ought to approach the welfare of the people of rural and provincial Australia it is worth casting back one's mind to the atmosphere in rural and provincial Australia in 1974-75. I say that not trying to be divisive in this matter but because it is a reminder of the approaches which produced a very adverse reaction in the areas on behalf of which Senator Button purports to speak today.

A list of the seats which were lost by the Australian Labor Party in 1974 and 1975 is a pretty hard reminder of the failure of policies which did not look to the welfare of our export industries, which did not look to the control of inflation and which did not look to keeping Australia competitive in the international markets on which we are so dependent. When one sees electorates such as Eden-Monaro, Hume, Macarthur, Macquarie, Mitchell and Riverina in New South Wales, Casey, Diamond Valley, Holt and La Trobe in Victoria, Bowman, Capricornia, Dawson, Leichhardt and Wide Bay in Queensland, Kingston in South Australia, the largest electorate of all, Kalgoorlie, in Western Australia and Bass, Braddon, Franklin and Wilmot in Tasmania one is entitled to stop and think about just what are the policies which are likely to benefit the areas that are so well represented in the list of electorates and which will meet the sorts of problems which have been raised by Senator Button today.

The Government has, in fact, drawn back from believing that a positive program of regional development is the answer to the problems of the people of those areas. It is true that the previous Government experimented with growth centres and that the present Government provided funds for certain regional development programs which were referred to by Senator Button a few minutes ago. The approach which we have adopted in a much more substantial way to spread benefits through the whole of the local government areas of Australia is much more likely to provide genuine benefits to the areas about which we are concerned today. I refer to the reforms which were instituted by this Government and which provided untied revenue sharing funds to local government for the first time. In 1981-82 a total of $350.9m will go to local government through that tax sharing formula; that is an increase of 16.7 per cent in one year and it is an increase, in real terms, of 139 per cent since 1975-76.

When one is looking at the sort of quantum of assistance which is flowing from central government to the more regional arms of government in this country it is quite clear that we are talking in very large amounts. Senator Button talked with approval of a program which spent, in total, $36m over a number of years fostering decentralisation. He was referring then to a program of the Fraser Government. That sum is a little over one-tenth of the amount which is made available to local government authorities under the tax refund scheme which was instituted by the Government. In fact, a very substantial and new contribution is being made to the areas to which Senator Button refers by the Federal Government through this mechanism of providing grants to local government. The fact that the grants are untied and are spent at the discretion of the local authority and not at the direction of the Commonwealth Government means that they are of particular value since they can be applied as the people of the local region believe that they should be applied. It is scarcely surprising to find that the expenditure of those moneys varies very considerably from area to area. Certainly a good number of authorities have chosen to use at least part of that supplement from the Commonwealth to expand their activities in the fields of social concern, which are the areas that Senator Button suggested were areas of neglect in rural and regional areas. We have moved not from a more generous to a less generous system of assistance to these regions, but, indeed, we have moved to make more available to them from the national purse.

As I said, the health of most of these areas is dependent on their economic health. One has to look only at the provisions for primary industry which were effected by the previous Government, and which have been effected by us, to understand why there has been concern in rural areas of Australia about the policies of the previous Government and such support for the policies that we have put forward. I have already mentioned the concern that was felt in those areas about the inflation that we were suffering and about our inability to compete in overseas markets. There are more direct policy areas, such as the abolition of the superphosphate bounty, the abolition of the fuel equalisation scheme, the abolition of the investment allowance tax incentives, the reduction of tax concessions for water, soil and fodder conservation, the repeal of the 100 per cent tax write-off provisions in any year for certain primary production capital equipment and the substitution of a 10 per cent write-off per year over 10 years, the failure to extend unemployment benefits to primary producers, the reduction of the distance for installation of telephone lines in country areas to only eight kilometres, the deterioration of rural roads during that period and the reduction of the minimum reserve price of wool by 50c a kilo. That list, which is by no means complete, is part of the story why rural and provincial Australia was less than charmed with the record of the previous Government.

I contrast that with the record of this Government which has worked to improve the competitiveness of Australian primary industry on which so many of those areas are heavily dependent. I refer to the expansion and consolidation of overseas market opportunities and the assistance in the improvement of amenities for rural people, especially those in remote areas. Let me be quite specific. We have improved tax averaging and introduced income equalisation deposits; we brought back the investment allowance on plant and equipment; we set up the Primary Industry Bank of Australia which, up to June 1981, has lent $360m to nearly 5,000 primary producers; we abolished Commonwealth estate and gift duties ; we vastly improved wheat pricing and marketing arrangements; we provided stabilisation and price support schemes for wool, wheat, fruit and dairy products; we provided an $80 a tonne subsidy on reticulated and bottled liquefied petroleum gas for household use; we provided a 100 per cent write-off in the year of expenditure on the cost of providing bores, wells, dams and reticulation facilities; we improved telephone services and rural roads; and we have provided assistance for isolated children and introduced a patients travel and accommodation assistance scheme. Those lists which cover, in part, not only economic areas of assistance but also other important social areas of assistance , such as the assistance for isolated patients in need of special attention and additional assistance for isolated children needing special assistance in their education, demonstrate the concern of this Government for rural and provincial Australia.

The words of the Leader of the Opposition sit rather oddly with the list I went through earlier of the Australian Labor Party's record of non-achievement for rural Australia in 1972-1975. Part of the concern expressed related to the provision of Government services for the people of rural and provincial Australia. My own Department is critically important to the lives of a very substantial number of Australians, including many Australians who live in those areas. Let me very quickly refer to the things that are being done by my Department to improve the quality of service to people in those areas. We have continued a policy of decentralising the operation of the Department. In 1975 there were 107 regional offices of the Department; in 1982 there were 164 regional offices. They serve in a very valuable way the people that we are concerned about today. We have developed the visiting services which are undertaken by field staff to many smaller centres. At present we have 350 services of that sort operating in these areas. We have developed regional rehabilitation units so that rehabilitation can be available to rural and provincial city dwellers as well as to metropolitan city dwellers. These were established in 16 locations-15 of them in country centres. With respect to Aboriginals, an important client group of my Department in many areas, the first Aboriginal liaison officer was appointed in 1975-an initiative of the previous Government. We have expanded that program and at present there are 29 Aboriginal liaison officers. We have honorary information officers in 75 different centres. We have a pilot program involving the appointment of 10 paid agents in rural centres which are not large enough to support a full time office.

I have referred in some detail to the moves being taken within my Department and moves which have already been taken within my Department to ensure that the social service requirements of rural people are met in the same way as social service requirements of city people. Problems remain. A problem that we are currently addressing is the problem of the rural unemployed who sometimes with the lodgment of unemployment forms by post suffer losses which are not suffered by their city brethren. That is a matter that is currently receiving attention. In this area, as in many others, I admit that things remain to be done. But I point to that list of achievements as evidence of our concern about rural and provincial Australia and as an earnest of our endeavours in this area.

In the field of communications-certainly when I visit the remoter parts of Australia this is central to the people's concerns-I point to a series of changes which again have greatly improved the amenity of many rural and provincial areas. In telecommunications, as recently as January the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) announced a new policy on country line charges which dramatically reduced charges for rural subscribers. The details of that were set out publicly by the Minister at that time. As far as postal services are concerned, in New South Wales six country mail centres serving areas within 400 kilometres of Sydney have now been brought into operation. Perhaps most importantly, in the field of broadcasting, in the remote area television program , 77 stations are to be established from 1979 to 1983 and 50 stations are already operating. If one looks to what this Government is pursuing with respect to satellite communications one finds that homestead and community broadcasting satellite services will provide additional radio and national television services to outlying areas. The national satellite system will provide improved educational services to people in remote areas.

None of these acts is the act of a government which is careless of the concerns of rural and provincial Australia. I go back to the point at which both Senator Button and I started: Fundamentally, those areas of Australia, in common with the rest of Australia, depend for their amenities, for their convenience and for their suitability as a place for Australians to lead good lives on the economic health of Australia. There is no way that any inquiry or any government programs will insulate the people of Australia from the economic realities that underpin all of our activities. For that reason the areas which are the subject of concern today have as strong an interest as any other part of Australia in careful economic management. It remains true that Australia cannot always meet all of the expectations of its people-that holds true for the people in our crowded cities, as it holds true for the people who live in remote and lonely parts of the country. The fact is that those expectations can be met only out of the production of wealth. The areas about which we are concerned certainly do their share-many would say more than their share-to produce wealth for this country. The Government remains committed to keeping Australia a sound place for the businesses and the productive activities that operate in those areas so that they can be sound places for people to lead their lives and to bring up their children.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Primmer Sen C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The previous speaker, the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney), about two-thirds of the way through his speech seemed to be seeking to make a great deal of capital when he started talking about tax concessions for farmers and high prices or reasonable prices for primary produce . It is fairly obvious to any of us who have lived all our lives in country areas that government measures such as these do not by and large do much for people living in the small towns and provincial cities throughout the length and breadth of this country. In fact, one wonders just how many farmers even benefited from tax concessions to sink dams or wells. The Government seems to have the opinion that when it introduces measures such as this every farmer in Australia rings up a boring contractor the next day and goes about making a sieve of his paddock, putting down bores ad infinitum. I suggest to the Minister that the great majority of farmers in Australia who have been on their land for 10 years have all the bores and all the dams sunk that they are ever likely to sink during their lifetime on their properties. So, it is a bit of a political kite-flying exercise to talk about matters that do not affect by and large the great majority of the Australian people living outside our metropolitan areas.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the great declines that we have seen in rural areas in the last couple of decades, I suppose, has been the downturn in processing of agricultural produce in country areas-our wool, our wheat and so many more of our agricultural products are by and large shipped abroad. The only Australian labour input in many of those industries is by the farmer, by the transport operator in carting the produce to the seaboard and by a few wharfies loading it at the various sea ports. That, I believe, has been one of the great reasons for the quite substantial increases in unemployment in our rural areas.

Quite frankly, this Government has made ad hoc decision making into an art form . I suppose that there is no better example of that than very early in the Fraser years when the decision was taken to curtail for the timebeing the building of the animal research laboratory in Geelong. If my memory serves me correctly, something like 18 months were lost because of an ad hoc, top of the head, decision by the Fraser Government-possibly high up in that Government- without any proper discussion throughout the proper government decision-making bodies in the Government parties to curtail the building of that laboratory. That is very typical of the sort of ad hoc decision-making that this Government has been conducting since coming to office. Because of this type of ad hoc decision making, this inability to look ahead and plan on some sort of reasonable basis, the whole of Australia will carry the scars for a long time to come.

Of course, I suppose one of the most recent ad hoc decisions was the one to set up the so-called razor gang that slashed wildly, mercilessly and madly in all sorts of areas because, it would appear, some Minister or some person in that razor gang had a bit of a hang-up about something or other in the life of this country. There was no planning, no rational decision-making, just slash and kick . It is a bit like the old story about Australia generally: If it stands still, chop it down; if it runs, shoot it. That is the philosophy which, in my view, the razor gang adopted. As I have said before, the nation will continue to suffer. What was one of the first decisions of the razor gang to affect rural and provincial people in Australia? It took the Commonwealth Government out of regional development. Further, it abolished the Decentralisation Advisory Board. In the years that I have been interested in politics the Liberal and National Country parties have always made great play in the length and breadth of this country about decentralisation and what they are going to do about it. Of course , another ad hoc decision took the Commonwealth Government out of the field of decentralisation. It said, of course, that the States should retain this responsibility with no question whatsoever of funding the Senates to do anything about it.

I suggest that generally we have seen a decline in decentralisation in Australia in the Fraser years, particularly since the advent of the razor gang. Any decentralisation that is occurring is occurring in a haphazard and unplanned way. As we well know, it is occurring in some of our developing resource areas in such places as Gladstone and the Latrobe Valley and Portland in my State. But , my God, it is a sight for sore eyes to see the way in which it is being done- no rationalisation, no planning whatsoever, with people being uprooted from their homes because no one first planned a proper housing program. Elderly people, pensioners and unemployed people are being turfed out of their homes because they cannot afford the rents that the resource boom allows owners of property to charge. The development is unplanned in that roads and rail and shipping facilities are all left to the States, which in turn do not seem able to cope with the problem; and chaos reigns supreme. There are caravan parks the length and breadth of the Latrobe Valley in Victoria because of the failure of the Federal and State governments to plan housing projects before the development program got under way. They are mobile slums in which thousands of Australian workers and their wives are bringing up their children today. Yet this Government talks with pride about Australia being one of the world's greatest nations of home owners. It is obvious that the people who espouse those ideas do not travel around some of the areas that I travel around in my State and see the poor housing and the terrible conditions under which people are obliged to live in this modern day and age.

What else did we see the razor gang institute? It declined to carry on any expansion of regional offices of the Department of Social Security. Anybody who, like me, lives in a town where one of those offices is established will have noticed that the staff and facilities in the regional offices of the Department of Social Security are totally inadequate to carry out properly the job that the Act asks them to do. The same applies to the Commonwealth Employment Service, where there is again a decline in service and facilities while thousands of young Australians walk the streets and wonder where they can get jobs.

The razor gang too deferred the building of Commonwealth offices in Townsville. The Fraser Government declined to foster the on-going program of the Whitlam Labor Government in relation to the expansion of government offices in rural Australia. At the time of the demise of the Whitlam Labor Government there were plans afoot for quite extensive development of Commonwealth Government offices in a large number of the provincial cities in my State of Victoria. All those plans have been laid in the dustbin by the Fraser Government since it came to power.

The fourth item that I have listed as resulting from the activities of the razor gang is the insistence on the amalgamation of a large number of colleges of advanced education. That again was a decision made off the top of the head of the razor gang-slam, bang, cut and thrust, with no question of discussing the problem with the people who run those institutes. As a consequence, chaos has since reigned throughout that area. These forced amalgamations and the curtailment of some educational services in many of the institutes have hit hard thousands of rural students. Last year we had the classic case of the curtailment of the School of Engineering at the Bendigo College of Advanced Education. Of course, that decision has now been compounded by the more recent action in relation to the Bendigo Ordnance Factory. Bendigo is a city which was once proud of its engineering abilities and its engineering background and which stayed stable largely because of its interest in engineering. That city will now go down the drain, in that respect anyhow, if this Government stays in office for much longer.

One can continue to go through the decisions of the razor gang. The decision of the razor gang to get the Fraser Government out of the area of soil conservation was, in my view, one of the greatest crimes that any federal government has committed, or may well commit, against the rural people of Australia and against the nation generally. The decision was made without any consensus and without any discussion with anyone. A recent television program on this very question showed that approximately one-third of the land mass of this country is affected in some way or another by soil erosion, water erosion, salinity and wind erosion . The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation has measured that in some areas there has been a loss of 80 tonnes of topsoil per acre per annum. Let us just reflect that, when all the mineral wealth of this country has been exported, the only area for the provision of wealth for the people of Australia will be those five or six inches of topsoil. Yet this Government got out of that field and claims to be the farmers' friend. I suggest that that alone should condemn the Fraser Government forever in the eyes of all Australians, in particular in the eyes of those people who live in rural areas and whose livelihoods in future will depend in one way or another on production from the soil of this country. One can go on and on.

The only other area I wish now to comment on is the savage decline in welfare housing in provincial areas. We can thank the Fraser Government for that. A friend of mine who lives in a city of 22,000 and who is interested in the building trade because he works on the periphery of it told me last Saturday that he took a drive around that city and could find only three houses under construction. Yesterday morning I had in my office two divorcees with three children. They were on the verge of tears because they could not get suitable accommodation. That shows the Fraser Government's attitude to people in country areas. It is a shocking record which will only be remedied the next time around.

Those people make up rural and provincial Australia. In many ways the prosperity or otherwise of the rural areas tends to pass by the vast bulk of people who live in the country. I am not talking about the graziers or the farmers, necessarily, but about the vast bulk of people who live in the small country towns throughout this nation. They, in many ways, subsist on top of the rural industries. These people never manage to get terribly well off as a result of rises in rural industries but they certainly lose their employment when conditions in various industries plummet.

The Australian Democrats believe that if we are to get anywhere in relation to reasonable rural policies in this country we must indeed get away from pulling out a decentralisation policy and waving it around every three years at election time. Indeed, every Bill that comes into this House has to be considered for its impact on everybody in Australia. I wish to raise a number of current issues to point out the path that we believe this chamber and the Parliament ought to take . The Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) mentioned the Government's policies. Indeed, we commend the Government for the advances it has made in relation to the provision of more adequate telephone services in rural areas. However, the Government should be looking at providing an equal base. After all, that is all that the National Farmers Federation seeks and that is the basis of the approach of the Australian Democrats. The people in the rural areas are not looking for subsidies or hand-outs; they are the last thing people in the country want but they have been offered them time and again. They are looking for an equal base with people in the cities. Then it will be up to them to attract industry and to work hard. When one goes and talks to the people in the country the attitude that one gets is that they are not interested in hand-outs and subsidies; they are interested, however, in equal treatment from the Government. I believe that if we get agreement on all sides in this House that that is the way the rural sector wants to be approached then we could have some intelligent and useful debates on each matter as it comes before us.

In relation to telephones, if we are seeking to give equal opportunity we may attempt to base charges not on distance, which the Government is doing currently , but on time. In other words, charges could be based on a two minute or three minute unit, or whatever is acceptable. The Government should look at that notion to see whether it is a practical and worthwhile policy to implement. Certainly, if that policy were capable of implementation, given the technical systems that Telecom Australia has available to it-from what I can discover it is possible-we could provide in one swoop an enormous capacity for the rural sector to attract industry to towns and provincial areas of this nation. Indeed, it would not mean that we would have to increase costs anywhere or that we would be providing a hand-out. We would simply be charging the method of charging.

Another matter that has become contentious over recent weeks is the purchase of the new aircraft carrier. While this decision may seem to be quite remote from rural areas, the point of view that the Australian Democrats puts in relation to this is very clear. The beef industry is worth over $11,000m to Australia. If there is anything that needs defending it is our rural industries. If we were to look at a sensible defence system we would look to providing an immediate defence for those rural industries against foot and mouth disease. It naturally flows from that that we should be looking at a range of patrol craft that could provide us with greater coastal surveillance. At the moment we do not seem to have an imminent wartime threat, but we do have, as of today, a threat to a major rural industry from foot and mouth disease. The suggestion that the Australian Democrats are making is that when any matter comes before this Parliament it must be considered in terms of rural Australia as well as urban Australia. While urban Australia discusses the aircraft carrier purely in terms of a military attack, rural Australia is certainly crying out for some defence against imminent attacks that may occur on our rural-based industries.

There is another major issue that the Australian Democrats believe needs to be raised. After the abortive attempt following the recent report on zone allowances, the Government should look again at zone allowances and come up with a reasonable proportion. If one considers the allowance as it was in 1945-it was then a deduction and now it is a rebate-and makes adjustments for the tax law changes that have occurred since that time, an average wage earner who now earns $14,430 would be paying, if that zone allowance were in force as it was at that time, only $545 tax. We believe that a very good argument could be put in relation to that zone allowance. It is not a question of providing a hand-out or a subsidy; it is a question of justice in terms of how much of the rural dollar is being actually spent in the rural area. For example, almost the entire amount spent on cultural activities by the Federal Government and large amounts of the medical dollar bypass country areas and are not used by the people in the country. The education dollar is not spent anywhere near as fully in the country as it is in the city and cannot be taken advantage of by people who live in the country without additional personal expense.

We believe that on any reasonable basis all of those matters would lead one to accept the proposition that to revert expenditure to an equal base a reasonable zone allowance would be needed. That allowance should not be calculated on the rather absurd A, B and C basis that exists at the moment. It would have to be worked out on the basis of individual shires and their cost structures. Those figures are already available and could form the ready basis for a comprehensive and coherent policy on zone allowances. We believe this is long overdue. Anybody who talks to country people can see that that is so.

The Australian Democrats believe that the political division that has grown up- partly fostered by division on party lines-between town and country is not and has never been profitable to Australia. To get a reasonable approach one would have to look at the notions that I have put forward today. If somebody came to Australia and was told that a farmers' party had been in power in this country for the last quarter of a century, that person would believe that many things in the country would be in place. We have today raised the notion of being able to go to an airport and get a reasonably frequent flight to major population and trade centres of rural Australia. I am quite sure that Senator Collard, who will follow me in this debate, will say that he would certainly like some reasonable flights to many parts of rural Australia that he visits. Those flights are not in place.

A visitor to the country would imagine that country people would have reasonable road networks. Yet the current Government is looking at a method which will disadvantage severely many of the rural shires. One town which I visited recently will lose 30 of its workers because the Federal Government wishes to introduce a tender basis for road construction in the shire. Thirty families will be lost from that town. I do not know whether many honourable senators visit small rural towns. The rural town to which I have referred will lose one-tenth of its population if it loses 30 families. That is the level at which rural towns subsist. They are not being supported by the policies that the Government has introduced in recent times. I believe that the Government has failed to take note that the policies it brings forward must not only be fair to people who live in urban Australia but also must take into account the specific and detailed problems from which people who live in rural Australia suffer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing a matter of public importance, namely, 'the Government's neglect of the people of provincial and rural Australia'. One only wonders why the Australian Labor Party has sought to bring on this matter for discussion at this time or, indeed, at any time. I suppose it may be a little euphoric after the results of the Lowe by-election on Saturday in that little town of Sydney in New South Wales. Of course, it is a rather insignificant place when it comes to the production of food, fibre and the general wealth in Australia today. Be that as it may, that is the discussion with which we are confronted today.
—That is a typical Country Party statement.

—And a Queenslander's too. It is quite interesting that all along the line the ALP has recognised the fact that it does not effectively represent rural Australia; that is, the part of Australia which provides the food, fibre and wealth for this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I recall that Mr Hayden, at an ALP rural seminar in 1979, said:
I don't dispute that in some ways the Labor Government was naive in its attitudes to rural policy and to country people.
Later that year, at the Victorian ALP Country Conference, he said:

There are a number of reasons for this marked decline in Labor's rural representation and prestige . . . The Party has also had problems in finding candidates with the mix of qualities attractive to the country electorate.

There are problems within the Labor Party in representing the areas of Australia that are responsible for our wealth and the high standard of living that everybody enjoys. Over the last few years there have been vast changes in rural Australia, as we all recognise. I was living in the north-west of Queensland when vast changes were brought about by seasonal conditions and the downturn of the wool industry. As well as the seasonal conditions, we have seen the changes in our markets. During the 70s there was a great plummet in the beef market. That industry was affected by seasonal changes but it was also affected by marketing conditions, particularly the effect of the policies of the European Economic Community. It is on record how the Minister for Trade and Resources (Mr Anthony) has, over a long period, hammered on the doors of the EEC to bring about changes. He has met with some success but not nearly enough. We all concede that there are problems in rural Australia, but I utterly reject the view that rural areas have been neglected. From listening to previous Government speakers one could take almost a whole debate in listing all that has been done for rural and provincial Australia.

Senator Macklin mentioned at length some of the problems concerning exotic diseases that might get into Australia. I thought it rather ironic that a member of the Australian Democrats was talking about 'foot and mouth disease'. The Democrats seem to suffer from it regularly. The Cocos Islands quarantine station has been brought on stream in recent times. I was privileged to meet with some of the cattle breeders of Australia when the first shipment of cattle was brought into Australia through that station. It means that we can bring important new bloodlines into our great herds in Australia. This can be done relatively easily compared with the quarantine restrictions in the old days. The station was established at a not insignificant cost. The laboratories being set up in Geelong will work hand in hand with it to help bring the total quarantine system to fruition.

Some speakers, including Senator Macklin, touched upon the role of communications and transport in rural Australia. It is in the realm of telecommunications that we have seen some of the greatest changes over the last few years in order to try to bring to the people who need it most a service that they have not had and, unfortunately, in some circumstances still, do not have. A dramatic change in charging was announced recently. Prior to that, we saw the reduction of subscriber trunk dialling charges, trunk line charges and the implementation of Community Access 80 which meant that anybody with a telephone in a country area could have access to his centre of business for a standard 10c fee, as it then was, for a three-minute call. That was a tremendous breakthrough for people in rural areas. Since then we have seen a marked reduction in connection fees. I firmly believe that there should be a common connection fee. At present we have not quite reached that stage, but whereas people were once faced with a connection fee of thousands of dollars or a $500 per year rental fee which would go on ad infinitum, the maximum fee for connection to an automatic exchange is now $1,350. The maximum amount for those people converting to a manual exchange is $1,750. The maximum rural conversion fee for those people already on a part privately erected line is $600. This is a tremendous breakthrough when we consider what these people had to look forward to prior to that. But I am the first to admit that this is not good enough. I am a great advocate of a common connection fee right around Australia. That is what we want . I want to see that first before even such things as time charging, as was mentioned by Senator Macklin. Time charging has been looked at. Quite a massive capital cost is involved in instituting that. I think it is a matter of value judgment as to which is instituted first. But I want to see people without phones with phones before I see changes in the charging system. This is for the simple reason that there is only so much available in capital funds. As I said, I want to see that money used for people who have not already got phones.

We have seen a great revolution in communications. The first experiments with radio concentrators were done in my area. This meant that lines did not have to be laid and that people could get their telephones a lot sooner than they might have expected. There was a lot of heartburn and expense as those experiments went on. Suffice it to say that over a period it was successful, and now those radio concentrators are being put to greater use throughout rural Australia. I understand that Telecom Australia has drawn up specifications for digital concentrators and has called for tenders for their production. This will mean enhanced usage for those people looking at a long waiting time before receiving their phones. Of course, need I mention the satellite which we as a government are committed to? What will it do? Of course, it will make a lot of difference to the propagation of television and radio with the dissemination of services from metropolitan areas to people who could otherwise not have a television service. I think the most important thing that that satellite will do for Australia is to provide people who would not normally have a telephone for many years to come with a telephone in the foreseeable future. The satellite is another government initiative in the way of communications. As I said, the satellite covers telephonic, television and radio communications.

Mail services suffered dreadfully with the rural downturn in Australia. As people left rural areas in vast numbers the carrying contractors, who usually had the mail contracts, found it no longer viable to do carrying. Thus the mail contracts were also in jeopardy. A lot of rearranging had to be done in rural Australia. While that was being undertaken many people were hurt when their mail services dropped from three times a week to once a week or once a fortnight. I am glad to say that that situation is being reversed. Where delivery was once a fortnight it is now once a week and where it was once a week it is moving to twice a week with the reorganisation of mail services in rural Australia.

I think people should realise that there is massive cross-subsidisation of postal and telephonic communication services in Australia. In 1980-81 the cross- subsidisation of rural postal services amounted to $25m. On top of that the subsidisation of registered publications was $19m. Of course, a lot of that went to rural Australia and assisted in the dissemination of knowledge. The cross- subsidisation in Telecom for rural Australia in 1980-81 is estimated at $350m. Of that amount $20m is used for telegrams. Recently the charges on telegrams for those people who have no other method of communications-those on outpost radio and on the Royal Flying Doctor Service radio-were reduced. That is an area of cross-subsidisation. Massive cross-subsidisation occurs for both rural telephonic and postal services.

In every Budget since this Government came to power there has been massive assistance to rural industries. I find it ironic that the Labor Party has brought this matter up for debate. We have set aside so much money for the fertiliser bounties. Of course, a lot of money goes into rural research, the beef carcass classification scheme and the beef export inspection and animal health services. The list is almost endless. On top of that we have the domestic sugar pricing formula which means that the sugar industry in the domestic market can look towards a guaranteed income. That formula takes into account the effect of inflation and increases in the cost of fuel and fertilisers. Australia is part of the International Sugar Agreement. This is something which was hammered out over a number of years and which stabilised the world-wide sugar industry. The only wild card in the pack is, once again, the European Economic Community. We also have the wheat stabilisation scheme and the wool marketing reserve price scheme.

The prices received for most primary producers often do not bear any relation to cost of production but are basically what the market can bear. By comparison in other industries prices for products and services are based on cost and people work for set wages. Most primary producers are not in that position. Therefore, it is essential that we have a strong economy. Of course, it has been one of the Government's aims to reduce inflation because it is the rural sector of Australia which is hurt most when inflation gets out of hand. I think we have done that-of course, not as successfully as we would like but with a certain amount of success.

Rural industry is hurt as much as any other section of the economy when interest rates blow out. I find it rather ironical that those who sit on the Opposition benches, as late as last week, took part in depriving this Government of much needed revenue when they rejected the sales tax legislation. That is having an effect not only on the Commonwealth but also on the States. It means more pressure for inflation, there is more pressure on interest rates and there is less money to provide some very necessary services for rural Australia. I reject the claim that the Government has neglected the people of rural and provincial Australia. I move:
That the business of the day be called on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL LAND RIGHTS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Peter Baume) agreed to:

That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 and the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Act 1979, and for related purposes.
Bill presented, and read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: -I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill is designed to meet a number of specific objectives. The first of these is to meet the wishes of the people of Hermannsburg in the Northern Territory about the grant of title to their land. Honourable senators may be aware that the Hermannsburg lease is one of the areas listed in Schedule 1 of the Aboriginal Land Rights Act to be granted to Aboriginal trusts. It has not been so granted-and it is the only land in Schedule 1 which has not yet been granted-because the leaders of the traditional land-holding groups in the Hermannsburg area did not want to accept a single title for the whole area, as Aboriginal people elsewhere in the Territory had done. Instead, they wanted five land trusts, each to hold separate titles to different parts of the land. As the Act is drawn, only one trust can be established for each of the areas of land described in Schedule 1. The proposed amendments will permit the establishment of more than one land trust for the Hermannsburg area.

The leaders at Hermannsburg also said that they did not want to have a chairman of each of the trusts as provided in the Act and that, in at least one case, there were only three people who could properly be appointed members of the trust. At present the minimum requirement is a chairman and three other members. The amendments will allow the establishment of trusts with a minimum of three members and without a chairman.

The second objective is to allow the redrawing of the boundaries of the land held by the Tiwi Land Trust. The Tiwi people of Bathurst and Melville Islands have asked that Clift Island, a small island which lies off the west coast of Bathurst Island, should be included within the land trust area. The Northern Territory Government has supported this request. The Bill provides for the amendment of Schedule 1 to include all land lying within 5.56 kilometres of the low water mark within the description of Bathurst Island. The Tiwi Land Council has also sought the consolidation of the titles granted to the Tiwi Trust in respect of Bathurst Island and Melville Island and the Bill provides for this.

A third aim of the Bill is the extension of the provisions for financial assistance to people appearing before the Aboriginal Land Commissioner in relation to an application for the restriction of access to an area of sea adjoining Aboriginal land. Section 54C of the Act provides a procedure by which people appearing before the Commissioner in relation to land claims may make application to the Commonwealth Attorney-General for financial assistance. The Government considers that it is reasonable for the Commonwealth to extend this provision to people appearing in closure of seas hearings since these are conducted pursuant to the Northern Territory Aboriginal Land Act, which was introduced as part of the package of legislation complementary to the Commonwealth land rights Act.

In addition the Bill provides for a more practical system of repayments from the Aboriginal Benefit Trust Account to the Consolidated Revenue Fund in respect of moneys advanced to land councils by the Commonwealth to meet their administrative expenses. Advances were necessary because payments into the Trust Account equivalent to royalties received by the Crown in respect of mining on Aboriginal land were insufficient to meet the administrative costs of the land councils. I point out to honourable senators that the Aboriginal Land Rights ( Northern Territory) Amendment Act 1979 already provides for the repayment of such moneys but as a once only lump sum payment. The amendments will provide the Minister with a discretion to direct periodical repayments from the Trust Account to the Consolidated Revenue Fund taking account of the capacity of the Fund to meet such repayments. It should be noted that these payments will not reduce the funds available for distribution to Aboriginals generally in the Northern Territory from the Trust Account. Repayments will be made when the amounts available for distribution to land councils under section 64 (1) of the Act are greater than are needed to meet their administrative expenses and will simply reduce the surplus available for distribution by land councils to communities in their areas.

A further aim is to remove any doubt that might exist as to the Minister's ability to make progressive recommendations to the Governor-General for the grant of land to an Aboriginal land trust following receipt of a report by the Aboriginal Land Commissioner. By way of example, the Land Commissioner has recommended that there are some areas in the Alligator Rivers region which should be granted to a land trust. These areas could now be granted, except for some parcels of land within the claim area which are currently the subject of, or may be affected by, certain applications now before the High Court. The amendments would permit the Minister to deal immediately with those parts of the claim area not affected by the legal proceedings and allow those areas whic are affected to be dealth with at a later date. I am sure honourable senators will acknowledge that the interests of the Aboriginals and of the community in general are best served by expediting the issue of title following the consideration of a report by the Land Commissioner.

For similar reasons, it is desirable to have flexibility in the Act to provide for situations in which traditional owners may desire more or fewer land trusts than were recommended by the Aboriginal Land Commissioner in his report. It is important, I feel, to be able to respond to applications of that kind by a land council where that is appropriate. For instance, in the Borroloola land claim the Aboriginal people wanted a single land trust to hold the land for the benefit of both the island and the mainland people. They simply wanted to be seen as one people. But the Commissioner recomended that two trusts be established in respect of that land. The Act, however, did not allow the Minister at that time to accede to the request. The amendment will allow me to respond if that or a similar request in respect of trust holding arrangements is made in the future.

The land councils have been made aware of the proposed amendments. I table certain documents which indicate the responses of the councils to the proposals contained in this Bill. I do not consider this Bill to contain amendments which could be described as controversial but they are amendments which either derive directly from the requests of Aboriginal groups in the Northern Territory or are designed to facilitate the advantage of the Aboriginal people. So that the land councils may be aware of the provisions of the Bill I have today authorised copies of the Bill being made available to them, following this speech.

Finally, I wish to make it clear that these amendments are not in any way connected with other proposals that have been advanced in the discussions which are still in progress between the Commonwealth, the Northern Territory Government and the land councils about the land rights Act. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robertson) adjourned.

Motion (by Senator Peter Baume)-by leave-agreed to:

SOCIAL SERVICES AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1981 [No. 2] (1982)
Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Peter Baume) read a first time.
Second Reading

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

Honourable senators will be aware that clauses precluding spouses of persons involved in industrial action or who have by certain other actions demonstrated an 'unwillingness' to work from receiving unemployment and special benefit were deleted by the Government from the Social Services Amendment Bill 1981 during its passage through the Parliament. Those clauses were subsequently introduced into the Parliament, in the Social Services Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1981, which the Senate failed to pass last November after it had been passed by the House of Representatives.
This Bill re-introduces that Bill.

Before October 1979, the Social Services Act precluded payment of unemployment benefit to a person who was a direct participant in a strike. However, it enabled unemployment benefit to be paid at the 'married' rate to the spouse of a person ineligible for unemployment benefit on those grounds. The Act was subsequently amended to provide that unemployment benefit payable to the spouse of a person engaged in industrial action was to be at the 'single' rate. A further amendment precluded payment of special benefit to a person who, because of industrial action, was not qualified to receive unemployment benefit.

This Bill proposes that, for so long as a person's spouse is disqualified from receiving unemployment benefit because of involvement in industrial action; or unwillingness to undertake suitable work; or failure to take reasonable steps to obtain such work, that person will also be ineligible for unemployment benefit. Additionally, a person will be ineligible for unemployment benefit for so long as payment of that benefit to the person's spouse is postponed because of their misconduct as a worker; because they have become voluntarily unemployed; or because they have failed to accept an offer of suitable employment. Consistent with this approach, special benefit will also be withheld from persons not eligible for unemployment benefit in these circumstances.

The Government has decided, however, that if a person is precluded from receiving unemployment benefit and special benefit, in a case of extreme hardship and where there are no other means of support, that person's spouse may be eligible for special benefit at the single rate, with additional benefit for any children. This will ensure that cases of actual hardship can be assisted, in contrast with the present position where the social security system can be called upon in circumstances where there is no actual need.

Mr President, we are not here concerned to discuss the merits of strike action as contrasted with other means open to employees in dispute with their employers to resolve these disputes. What we are concerned with is how the cost of strike action is to be borne.

The Government holds strongly to the belief that these provisions should become law. In the case of the provisions relating to industrial action, we do not believe that Australian taxpayers should be asked to subsidise strike action through the social welfare system.

The policy underlying this Bill is that a person, when he chooses to take strike action, should act in the recognition that he takes responsibility for the consequences of his action, both for himself and for his family. Strikers make the decision to strike against the rest of the community, and they must bear the financial consequences, not the rest of the community through the welfare system. Trade unions, whether acting through their officials or by the vote of their members, should equally recognise that decision to initiate industrial action will have consequences for all members and their families which the community should not be asked to bear through the welfare system.
This is the proper perspective from which to consider the measures proposed in this Bill.

The Government is not swayed by emotional and mis-leading arguments which seek to deflect attention from and misrepresent that fundamental concern. The issue is quite clear, and we do not intend to be drawn into the kind of fruitless debate which seeks to direct attention away from the issue.
The Bill is not an 'anti-strike' Bill, but one which aims at restricting the community subsidisation of strikes.

The legislation as it stands at the moment permits a situation where trade unions can choose to strike, knowing that through the operation of the social security system their members can be largely insulated from the financial effect of their actions.

Unless frivolously or maliciously entered into, the object of a strike is to obtain, by the exercise of economic pressure directed against the employer, a benefit for those who take such action. As a result, the benefit sought is itself economic, such as increased pay, a shorter working week, or special allowances. Not infrequently, strikes are settled on a basis that effectively compensates those who have gone on strike for pay lost during the duration of the strike.

The point to be emphasised is that to strike is an exercise in freedom of choice. Generally, it is one taken by the membership of a union to promote its own interests and only its own interests. It is taken against the interests of the employer and, what is directly relevant to this Bill, it is one which is not taken in the interests of the community as a whole.

Indeed, the effect of strike action is often in conflict with the interests of the community as a whole or some part of it. Frequently, the community suffers as a result of strike action. This may be reflected simply in inconvenience or in terms of direct economic cost. Furthermore, in a larger sense, it may be said that in the longer term the community always suffers as the cumulative result of the strike action is to decrease the availability of goods and services, and sometimes to do great damage to particular sectors of the economy, or to particular employers.

These matters need only to be mentioned to make clear the absurdity of any argument that benefits should be paid to strikers or their families, and should be paid by the community at large. For it is the community at large that provides through taxation the funds from which strikers are currently paid the benefits that this Bill proposes to eliminate.

There have been numerous cases where the wives of strikers, who have appeared to have no genuine intention of joining the workforce themselves, have registered for work in places such as mining and construction towns where there is no real possibility of employment for them. This has enabled them, under the existing legislation, to obtain unemployment benefit, and so transfer to the taxpayer some of the real cost of the industrial action taken by their husbands. The burden so thrust upon the community is far from light. For example, honourable senators will recall that from 15 July 1981 to 28 September 1981 some 600 people were involved in a strike concerning the use of apprentices during industrial action at the Utah Development Co. mine in Central Queensland. Four hundred and seventy-one wives claimed unemployment benefit at a cost of around $ 40,000 per week, making a total cost of some $450,000.

So, the Australian public is attacked from two directions. First, it has to bear the personal disruptions, inconveniences and associated costs that result from the strike. In addition, it is then called upon to meet the cost of providing income support for the families of those involved in the strike.

To act to correct this situation is not to 'punish' or 'penalise' the families of strikers, but to ensure that people accept the financial consequences of their own actions and do not look to the rest of the community to bear the costs of workers and their families.

Similarly, there is no good reason why the community should automatically and immediately be expected to assume through unemployment or special benefit payments the normal financial responsibilities of people who are not willing to work, who voluntarily and without good reason give up their job, or who are dismissed through their own misconduct. This is happening at present, because the spouses of such people can register for employment in their own right and, if they are unable to obtain employment, can claim unemployment benefit both for themselves and for their 'dependent' spouses.

In this situation however, as with the strike situation to which I have earlier referred, the Bill also provides that, if a person is precluded from receiving unemployment or special benefit, that person's spouse may receive special benefit at the single rate, with additional benefit for any children, in a case of extreme hardship and where there are no other means of support. The very existence of this provision belies the quite false charge that the Bill will in any way 'punish' or 'penalise' families.

Mr President, we believe that whether people refuse to work because of industrial action or whether, in some other way, they show themselves unwilling to enter or remain in the workforce, there is no reason why the rest of the community should shoulder their financial responsibilities.
This Bill prevents them from manipulating the social security system to shift the consequences of their actions.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robertson) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES (TAX SHARING AND HEALTH GRANTS) AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Peter Baume) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The main purpose of this Bill is to amend the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Act 1981 to provide for:

(a) The payment in 1981-82 of additional tax sharing grants and special allocations totalling $69 million to New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland thereby bringing the aggregate tax sharing grant to be paid to the States in 1981-82 to $6689.7 million, and

(b) The payment in 1981-82 of a fixed tax sharing grant of $315.1 million to the Northern Territory in lieu of the amount which would be payable under the formula prescribed by section 8 of the principal Act.

At the Premiers Conference on 20 June 1981, at which the Commonwealth Grants Commission's report on State tax sharing entitlements 1981 was considered, it was decided that there would be no change in the relativities contained in the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Act 1981 in respect of the year 1981-82, and that the Commission should be asked to produce a further report on its assessment of States' relativities in the light of submissions to be put to it by States and by the Commonwealth. The Commission is expected to report by 31 May 1982.

In recognition of the likelihood that, following the further review, the State relativities would be adjusted in favour of the three most populous States, the Commonwealth agreed at the June 1981 Premiers Conference, to provide additional grants to New South Wales ($24.5 million), Victoria ($15.0 million) and Queensland ($20.5 million) in 1981-82.
