DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CENTRE FOR INTERNATIONAL AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 10 March, on motion by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had foreshadowed a number of amendments to be moved by the Opposition to this Bill regarding the life of the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research. As I recall, when the Bill was last before the chamber Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle was vigorously nodding her head-a matter which was not recorded in Hansard but which indicated to me that the Government would give serious consideration to those amendments. I have no doubt that Senator Peter Baume has not been informed of that but it is something that he might look into. The Bill contains what is fashionably called a sunset clause which provides for the organisation to disappear at the end of 12 years, with an effective review of its operations at the end of 10 years. The amendment that I have foreshadowed suggests that there be a review at the expiration of six years. The operation of the sunset clause would thereby come into effect after eight years. The reasons given for that were, briefly, that when people had served on the Policy Advisory Council for two terms of three years each it would be an appropriate time to examine how the organisation was going, how effective it was and whether it was appropriate to renew the terms of those involved in it.

SPEECH.PARA: There is one matter which I did not mention in discussing this Bill a week or so ago. That is simply the issue of land reform. The Bill provides an umbrella organisation in relation to Australian agricultural research with relevance to- for want of a better expression-developing countries or developing economies. The Opposition welcomes that initiative which means that research done in universities, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and a variety of other bodies can be brought together and co-ordinated for the benefit of the economies of underdeveloped countries. It seems to us to be a very rational way of handling Australia's contribution in this area. The only other point I make relevant to this legislation is that perhaps under the umbrella of an organisation like this Australian governments might be a little more active in encouraging land reform as a condition of assistance to underdeveloped countries. Research is very helpful and foreign aid is useful but in some countries, for technological reasons relating to the best use of land and so on, it might be desirable to consider policies of more encouragement for land reform and consolidation so that yields may simply give more wealth than they do at the moment.

In summary, we agree with the idea of creating the Centre as a clearing house for requests for assistance from developing countries in agricultural development. We think it is an excellent concept. We criticise it only on the basis that some of the administrative arrangements seem to us to be not necessarily wrong but less appropriate than they might be. We also welcome the notion of support at the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research for academic training for scientists from developing countries. We think that should be considered and that more attention should be given to the staffing questions associated with the establishment of a body of this kind. I conclude by saying that we welcome the Bill. At the seond reading stage we foreshadow amendments. We wish the organisation established by this legislation every success.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research Bill 1981. As a contribution to Australia's overseas aid the Centre will assume a role in the North-South dialogue. At the Cancun summit meeting on that subject last October the two co- chairmen, Mexican President, Jose Lopez Portilla, and Canadian Prime Minister, Pierre Trudeau, stated that leaders had committed themselves to working together to try to build an international economic order in which all states would be able to realise their potential with equal opportunities and in which the developing countries in particular would be able to grow and develop according to their own values. That growth is impossible without food security and agricultural development. In the spirit of the North-South dialogue, that calls for a transfer of resources in this most critical area from the developed to the developing countries of the Third World. Thus leaders at that conference saw as their first priority an obligation on the international community to eradicate hunger and to ensure food security.

SPEECH.PARA: There can be no doubt that the world food problem remains immense. Professor Harries, in the report of the Committee on Australia's Relations with the Third World, indicated that the number of people with a food intake below what he described as the 'critical minimal limits' has risen to an estimated 445 million , with over 60 per cent of them in Asia. Furthermore, he indicated that in order to feed the world population by the year 2000 at current dietary levels, world food production would have to increase by up to 60 per cent and that in developing countries an increase of about 75 per cent would be required. The Independent Commission on International Development Issues, more commonly referred to as the Brandt Commission, somewhat similarly showed particular concern at the gap between the production and consumption of cereals, which amounted to some 37 million tons in 1975 and which the Commission said might reach 120 million to 145 million tons by 1990. The Commission feared that such huge shortages might well cause mass starvation. In fact it has been suggested that since the Brandt report was published international food security has worsened. Wheat stocks as a percentage of consumption fell last year to the lowest level since World War II.

Thus the question is immediately raised as to how best Australia can contribute to solving this massive and critical problem. In an immediate sense there is no substitute for direct food aid. It is pleasing to note that our food aid has increased this year to $100m with a number of innovations, including payment of freight on an increased portion, the provision of 80,000 tonnes of freight paid grain to Africa on a bilateral basis but channelled through the world food program, and our contribution of at least 45,000 tonnes to the International Emergency Food Reserve. The subject of food aid is, however, complicated. Notwithstanding the demands made by some sections of the community, Australia has only a limited capacity to assist. Its exports of wheat, flour and coarse grains constitute less than 10 per cent of world total exports compared with over 65 per cent for North America. It cannot deploy the financial resources that Western Europe and North America have to support concessional commercial sales. Additionally, the provision of some sorts of food aid can have the unintended effect of inhibiting production and encouraging the recipient countries to postpone the adoption of appropriate development policies. To some extent this can be overcome by linking food aid to employment promotion and agricultural programs and other projects which do not weaken incentives to food production, as was canvassed in the Brandt Commission report.

Whilst in the short term only direct aid can relieve hunger, there can be no doubt that in the longer term the objective of helping to increase agricultural production in developing countries is paramount. The Cancun Summit stressed that food aid should not be used as a permanent replacement for the necessary development of the required food production in developing countries. With similar sentiment the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Melbourne, only weeks before, stated in its final communique that it 'recognised that the ultimate solution to the world food problem lay in greater self-sufficiency in developing countries'. Whilst this no doubt sustained and long term internal efforts by developing countries, there is a clear international responsibility, in the spirit of the North-South dialogue, for the provision of timely and sufficient technical and financial support. Professor Harries, in his report to which I referred earlier, offers the encouragement that there is adequate potential, in terms of the availability of land and scope for increased productivity in respect of existing land, for food production per capita in developing countries to be increased. He states:

If the necessary political will, application of technical know-how, provision of requisite capital and improvement of agricultural practices are applied universally through food producing areas in the developing countries, the prospect of avoiding general or widespread food should be good.

With this encouragement Australia has had to face its responsibilities of contributing to meet the desirable objective of greater self sufficiency in the Third World. There are clearly a number of ways in which this countribution could be made. Brandt stressed the need for agricultural infrastructure, particularly the requirements of irrigation and water management, and also roads , transport, rural electrification and distribution and provision of greater quantities of fertilisers and pesticides. In fact many of Australia's bilateral programs have placed considerable emphasis on rural development. Brandt also found the need to develop farming systems appropriate to local circumstances. Again Australia has contributed in this area through its significant aid training program and in the transfer of its technological skills and expertise which have contributed to such basic needs as better soil management. But in addition to the bilateral aid programs to develop the required infrastructure, training programs, technological transfer and the more difficult goals such as agrarian reform, which has been mentioned, a need for greater research has also been found.

Brandt stated that much more effort should be put into development and research where relatively modest sums can have a large and well demonstrated impact upon production. He gave the example that the continuing development and adaptation of new plant varieties depends on a sustained effort of research at international, regional and national centres. This need for expanded support for international agricultural research institutions is, of course, the motivating force behind the proposed centre. Professor Harries specifically saw the opportunity for Australia which presented itself when, in his report, he stated:

It would appear that unused potential exists for Australia's scientific resources to be put to more effective use in assisting to expand the technological efficiency of agricultural production in developing countries, by stepping up the quality of the available knowledge and advising innovative ways of effecting its transfer, especially to those countries most in need.

The Institute will not solve difficult political problems or provide the necessary development capital but it can provide assistance in the area of agricultural technology which some, such as Professor Harries, see as the greatest assistance Australia can render. In examining this new initiative it should not be thought that financial assistance for agricultural research and development in developing countries has been absent in the past. According to the second reading speech of the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle), Australia's contribution in the year 1980-81 was about $12m, which is not insignificant. We have supported the Consultative Group on International Agricultural Research and the maintenance of its 13 agricultural research centres around the world and, in particular, in our region, the International Rice Research Institute in the Philippines.

There can be little doubt that Australia is particularly well placed to assist developing countries in the area of agriculture, with expertise and experience in agricultural research and development over a wide range of climates and soils from dry land farming to tropical livestock and agricultural production. The work that has been done by the States, particularly in a demonstration and development capacity, in developing countries is well recognised. There is equally little doubt that adequate research capacity exists within Australian universities, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, the State departments of agriculture and other tertiary and commercial bodies. What has been missing, however, from the Australian agricultural research aid program is co-ordination. There has, as the Minister was prepared to admit in her second reading speech, been a lack of an effective mechanism to identify agricultural problems in developing countries systematically, to identify the areas of research required to contribute significantly to the overcoming of such problems and to marshall the collective expertise which exists within Australia to meet such research requirements.

The purpose of this Bill is primarily to set up an institute in the form of a statutory authority to formulate programs and policies with respect to agricultural research in areas of identifying agricultural problems and finding solutions to such problems in developing countries, to commission agricultural research by persons or institutions in Australia in accordance with such programs and policies, and to communicate to persons and institutes the results of such agricultural research. Thus it is designed specifically to meet the shortcomings in our current agricultural research program. Its formation should therefore be applauded. It is to be noted that there will be an initial commitment of $25m over four years to the trust fund set up for the centre. The initial funding is therefore significant and should be able to purchase considerable valuable research.

In this regard it is particularly pleasing that the administrative infrastructure of the centre will be kept to an absolute minimum in order that funds marked for research can actually be utilised for that purpose. It is also noted that the centre will be assisted by the Policy Advisory Council which will have expert rather than governmental representation from developing countries. Whilst the strength of the current bilateral aid projects has been that they were initiated on the advice of the recipient country, there has been a corresponding weakness in the possible political motivation of the request. In this instance it will be the function of the centre to identify and assist in particular agricultural problems. The move away from government to government aid will give the centre certain of the advantages of non-government organisations able to pierce the government veil. Notwithstanding that advantage , I must state that I have reservations in that the centre is to be yet another statutory authority.

This Bill is a public sign of Australia's commitment in a very rational way to the transfer of resources, which lies at the basis of the North-South dialogue, and the objective of assisting developing countries to grow and develop. It is also a furtherance of the major emphasis of Australian policy and the provision of high quality assistance without strings attached. In overseas aid there must, in addition to quality, be quantity. In that regard Australia must still strive to meet by 1990 the international accepted target of providing 0.7 per cent of its gross national product in development assistance. To place the quantity of Australian aid in its right perspective it should be recognised that our performance, currently 0.45 per cent of gross national product, has been consistently higher than the average of other highly developed countries. For example, the 1980 figure for the United States is 0.27 per cent, for the United Kingdom 0.34 per cent, for West Germany 0.43 per cent, for Canada 0.42 per cent and for Japan 0.32 per cent. By this Bill we are showing that we can meet the objective of quality. We must not, however use that to camouflage the objective of quantity. The formation of this Institute has been internationally applauded. The Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting welcomed the decision as did the Development Assistance Commission of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation an Development in its consideration in Paris in November of last year of Australia's overseas aid program.

The formation and successful operation of the Centre will not negate our responsibility in the areas of technological transfer, development of infrastructure and training. It will further not justify us from facing the detrimental effect international trade protection has on the economies of the developing world and their ability to sustain their population. It will not avoid the need to support international food security by concluding international grains agreements, by the provision of large international emergency reserves and the establishment of a food financing facility. It will, however, make a contribution to the challenge which the Brandt Committee saw: There is no more important task before the world community today than the elimination of hunger and malnutrition in all countries. The Centre, therefore, should be supported with enthusiasm.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research Bill which will establish an Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research and which will commission agricultural research to identify and find solutions to agricultural problems of developing countries. These are very worthy objectives. I only wish that the task was as easily achieved as it is defined. The Centre will also disseminate the results of the research. The Australian Democrats are pleased that this Bill introduces the sunset principle and that the centre will cease to be in force after 12 years. An opportunity for review will be given after 10 years. This has caused a bit of concern because any ongoing agricultural programs for Asia will not be disposed of in six or 10 years. I would have thought that there would be very little doubt in anybody's mind that this is an initiative that Australia would be happy to continue while it was needed.

SPEECH.PARA: This is not necessarily an organisation that will go on long after its need has passed, which is a reason for sunset clauses. This organisation is different: It is one where I think programs will begin and concrete results will be seen only after time spans of five to ten years. We were quite alarmed to see the proposed amendment of the Australian Labor Party which seek to reduce the period involved back to eight years so that programs will run effectively for six years before they are reviewed. The Democrats are unhappy about that. For those reasons the Australian Democrats will not support the proposed amendments. We believe that it is necessary to give a reasonable time to the programs which are embarked on in this Parliament.

I agree with the Labor Party-this may be its motivation perhaps-that we are being very hopeful. We are hoping that this will be a successful organisation, will be funded adequately and that there will be the enlightenment and flexibility of mind to ensure that it gets hold of the people who really know what they are talking about, the people who have been in village Asia and know what those people want, and gives them their lead. This has not always been the case in the past. One of the great tragedies of the world is that there has been an officious, well-intended feeling on the part of Western experts that to take Western experience in agriculture or anything else and hand it over, graft it, or transfer it to the village societies of Asia-fundamentally, in spite of their huge size they are village societies-is a good thing. Unfortunately the results, so far, have been tragically wrong in most cases.

I will give an example of a situation that I have witnessed personally. The first tributary scheme of the great Mekong Project was lauded some years ago as something that would transform Indo-China. The Nampong scheme, the first tributary hydro-electric development, flooded a huge area in north-eastern Thailand. Virtually all of the high quality rice land in the province was flooded. The farmers who were producing well were put off their land their land then flooded. The area there is unfortunate. It is situated in very low hills and a wide, flat basin. It is a very unpromising place for hydrodevelopment because of the shallowness of the storage and the relatively large flooding of land for the capacity involved. That turned out to be tragic in human terms and all others. The families who farmed that land have done so for longer than any person in Australia could comprehend, possibly for millenia. They were pushed off and not given any compensation. After many years they were given a small amount of money but were not given any land to work. Apart from providing a light to the neighbouring market town of Khon Kaen the last I heard was that the generators were still up to only a quarter of their capacity with no prospect in the future of ever being any real use to that community. The reason for this is that the society is a village-type society which cannot, in itself, make the quantum jump to a mechanised society. It is no good saying: 'Give them electricity, they will provide the industries and things will happen there. There will be a great industrial revolution and they will be fine'. In fact, that does not happen.

I am rather concerned at the reference in the second reading speech by the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) to the International Rice Research Institute in the Philippines and a subsequent reference that the achievements of these centres are already very considerable. That, of course, is true. They have produced a rice which is much higher producing and which gives much more capacity per hectare, but they paid a rather heavy price for the so-called 'miracle' rices. Those of us who reviewed the green revolution wonder, with hindsight, whether these rices which need fertiliser, insecticides and considerable capital to grow and which have led to a major change of land ownership in many parts of Asia-indeed, this occurred in India, the Philippines and Indo-China when the varieties were first brought in- are any better in the long term than the traditional rice varieties which, although they were lower yielding, were at least reliable. They were planted for generation after generation and were known to be resistant to disease. A stable situation had been created. More attention should be given to bringing more acreage into rice production. This is an engineering problem rather than an agricultural research problem. The same thought is reflected in the Minister's second reading speech where she states:
Research in industrialised countries tends to be concentrated on those agricultural commodities that are important to their own economies.
That is in industrialised countries-

Consequently, little attention is given to new ideas and techniques specifically related to agricultural production in developing countries. This is a limiting factor to increased food production in the developing countries.

The Australian Democrats found that paragraph in the Minister's second reading speech of very great reassurance. If that is the sort of thought that will inform this institute it will be moving along the right lines, it will be very useful and will be of use to the Third World countries. It recognises the need for a different type of research, a different type of approach from what is going on here. Agricultural research in Australia, some of which, as I will shortly describe, may well be of value to the Third World countries, is not necessarily of value to them in itself. I hope that there will be a tendency in this institute to counter the ever present impetus towards a drift away from subsistence crops to export or cash crops. This is another one of the great tragedies in Asia. This commercial motive has caused huge and disastrous famines , some of them not too long ago, which have killed many millions of people. It will cause them again if it is allowed to continue and if the basic need for these countries to produce enough food to feed their own people is overlooked. I think that is a point that should be made. I hope that the Centre in looking at agricultural programs will have the breadth of vision to look at that kind of very broad issue rather than say that countries should just plant this, that or the other thing.

I hope that the Centre will be generously funded and its priorities set on a basis of real need in the countries concerned. Too often in the past aid schemes -not so much ours; ours have been excellent, especially the Colombo Plan and earlier programs of that sort-have become a virtual handmaiden to those classes of Asian people near the top, as they see themselves, those commercial interests which have taken over farming land in many parts of that continent. They are interested only in export cash crops and do not care very much what happens to people if there is not enough food to eat.

We hope also for great flexibility so that work is contracted out to individuals, and organisations, who really understand the Third World's problems , who see the need for consultation at the village council level, and who, indeed, consult at that level. I say this from my own knowledge as a person who worked in north-east Thailand, one of the most remote and poverty stricken areas of Asia. There I met some of the most charming, intelligent and enlightened people I have ever met, none of whom could read or write. I am speaking of the village headmen and the members of the councils of some of the villages in that area in which I worked for nearly two years. They know very well what they want. Their difficulty is to find someone to listen to them and to what they want.

Villagers want quite plain things: They want fencing wire so that they can keep their animals enclosed; they want something which will create change. Their tragic situation is abundantly clear to anybody who goes into one of those villages where all the children have bulging bellies because they are on too high a carbohydrate diet. This, of course, is due to the tragic situation caused by our friend cassava, or tapioca, which has now become possibly the world's major food crop. It is almost pure carbohydrate. Village aid schemes need to look, I think-I found that village headmen and councillors realised this themselves-at encouraging things that would take care of the protein and fruit areas of their diets. They are looking out for such things as breeding eggs to produce improved poultry stocks, and grafted fruit trees. They, I believe, are prepared-I have heard this discussed with World Health Organisation people working well out in the country-to try to understand the need for a balanced diet. They had not really understood this before. They are prepared to be flexible enough to vary their agriculture to accommodate this if, indeed, somebody would come along and do it for them.

I am hopeful that these are the sorts of broad initiatives that will come from the Centre. There will be no difficulty about that because there are people at our universities who are like that. I know some of them. I hope that there will not be some sort of dreadful situation where some program is decided on by some mysterious process, perhaps by some consultative committee which does not really know what it is talking about or what it is doing. If we do not have that situation we will have a success with the Centre. Although this seems to be rather a minor Bill to the Senate at the moment, I doubt whether we could be doing anything very much more important than we are. We are here making a contact with tremendous potential which could benefit many hundreds of millions of people who are now ravaged by disease, people who have come to accept the fact that perhaps 30 per cent to 40 per cent of their children die before they reach 10 years. The problem is of that order. This is a project of high dignity, high promise and tremendous importance. The Australian Democrats hope that it is regarded as such universally.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a Bill to set up the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research. The function of the Centre is to mobilise and expand Australia's research capacity so as to assist developing countries in agriculture and related areas and to develop and expand a better co-ordinated and more identifiable Australian effort aimed at achieving nutritional self-sufficiency in developing countries. The Centre itself will not be engaged in any research work. It will contract out research work to bodies such as universities, State departments, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and private individuals and organisations. The support services for the Centre will be provided by the Australian Development Assistance Bureau-ADAB.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition supports the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research Bill but with some reservations. The Bill will not assist in the area of land reform, and that is something to which I wish to return after. The Bill contains provisions for a review of the Centre's operations after 10 years. We believe that is too long a period before it is reviewed. Senator Button, of course, will move amendments along those lines. We are concerned also that the resources of ADAB and the Department of Foreign Affairs are already overstrained with staff cuts resulting from the razor gang decisions and will not be able to assist the Centre properly. Further, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Street , said that all research work will be contracted out. We believe that research work should be given to the CSIRO rather than contracted out. We believe that it will be more expensive to contract research programs out than to allow the Government bodies to do the work.

In the recent parliamentary recess I was a member of a parliamentary delegation and an Australian Labor Party delegation that visited a number of countries in the Middle East. In perhaps nearly all of the countries that we visited we were shown agricultural projects. In particular, we were shown one in Egypt which is perhaps one of the most ambitious schemes that I have ever seen in the field of agriculture. It is hoped that in the end the town or the city that is involved in the scheme will have a population of 150,000. Two things in particular stood out and I think they are particularly relevant to this Bill: The first was how valuable Australian agricultural techniques and experiences are in the whole of the Middle East, and the second was how much Australia's programs of agricultural research and assistance in the Middle East need better co- ordination here in Australia. The Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research should be able to assist but I have doubts about it.

During that visit to the Middle East we visited two Australian agricultural projects in northern Iraq. The one at Mosul is being operated by the Western Australian Department of Agriculture and the one at Arbil, which is near the Iranian border, is operated by the South Australian Department of Agriculture. Both of those Australian projects have an excellent image. The Iraqi Government was particularly impressed by the fact that the Australians remained on the job after the war with Iran broke out. When we were there early in January Australian families were still on the job. They still had their children with them. They were still operating despite the fact that Iraq had been placed on a war footing.

TALK.START.PARA: —You had a helicopter ride, I understand.

—That is another matter. The South Australian project at Arbil is in the Kurdish area of Iraq. As I said, it is near the border with Iran. Earlier this year European tourists were kidnapped in the area. They have only recently been released. I place on record here this afternoon my appreciation of the dedication of those Australians who are working there and doing an excellent job under very difficult circumstances. As I said, these Australian projects are proving to be very successful. They are being helped by a fierce determination on the part of the local authorities to prove not only that the projects can be successful but also that locals can be trained to take over when the Australians leave. It was put to us by officials of the local council in the area that they are are asking the Australians to finish in 10 years what it would normally take the locals 100 years to do.

SPEECH.PARA: A large number of Middle East states are taking an interest in what Australia and Australian research institutions have to offer. It is not a question of aid, as it is in certain other parts of the world, because all of these states are able to pay for our expertise. Libya is one country that I give as an example. It has already offered large sums of money for Australian research and for Australian experts to work in that country. Australian State government projects at the moment are already being carried out in Libya, Jordan and the Sudan.
Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was commenting on the fact that a number of oil-rich Arab states are buying Australian agricultural expertise. They are also funding university programs and students. I was using Libya as an example and pointing out how recently the Government of Libya approached the New South Wales Government to take part in such a project. Its least consideration was how it was going to be financed; there was no problem at all about finance. What this Government should be doing is looking at making Australian agricultural expertise available to states which cannot afford it, particularly states in the Middle East and Africa. But that is a job which has to be done at Federal Government level, and it is also a task that needs a co-ordinated approach at that level.

SPEECH.PARA: Throughout the Middle East there is an obsession about food security, which countries in the area define as self-sufficiency. For example, the Saudi Arabian Agriculture Minister told our delegation that his Government was subsidising wheat production to achieve self-sufficiency at five times the average world price. The Saudis have as a near neighbour the Sudan, which is a poor state and which is in a much better position to act as regional producer of wheat, but the Saudis are prepared to pay five times the average world price to ensure that they have at least some wheat production of their own. They are concerned that countries such as Australia, the United States and Canada will remain reliable suppliers. They are also worried about whether in some circumstances we will be involved in food boycotts. They are aware that not just oil but also food are universally vital commodities in the hands of very few producers. This point was also raised with us by the Gulf Co-operative Council which is not only conerned about political stability in the area but is also vitally interested in food security. It is already suspicious of the United States policies on food boycotts and continually raised with us the point that they did not want to be placed in a position in which people could say to them: A bushel of wheat for a barrel of oil.

I now wish to turn briefly to the issue of land reform. I believe our overseas experience shows that, whilst our agricultural research is valuable, it is useless unless there is land reform in a number of countries that are receiving our aid. In too many parts of the world we see poor landowners being forced to give up their land to the wealthy landowners. They then work as labourers on what was their own land. They become dispirited when forced to do this and they finally drift into the cities to work in factories for low wages. There we have all the seeds for political discontent. I always remember former Senator Wriedt talking in this place about a similar institute to the one we are talking about tonight-the Institute of Tropical Agriculture in Nigeria. That is a magnificent project and it proves exactly what can be done, but I do not think it looks very carefully at what can be done on small landholdings.

Our aid program needs continued assessment. We need to examine some of our projects to see whether they should be continued or whether they should be modified. In the past I have drawn attention to the need to do this in areas such as the Philippines, and I was glad to hear that another honourable senator also raised this in the debate earlier today. One only has to look at the situation that has arisen today in Central America in countries such as El Salvador and Nicaragua to realise the need for land reform. We do not have to look that far way. We need only to look at a country such as New Caledonia, the nearest country to Australia to be involved in an independence struggle, to realise that the issue of land reform is one of the key issues behind the push for independence in that country. In New Caledonia the situation at the moment is that a majority of the good land is farmed by very few European farmers, whereas the thousands of Melanesians who do own land are farming on very small holdings indeed.

In summary, I think the creation of an agricultural research centre as a clearing house for requests for assistance from developing countries is excellent. I believe the administrative arrangements are inadequate. I think aid management in Australia needs to be improved and streamlined. As I said, land reform is the key issue with which the agricultural research centre should be concerned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In supporting the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research Bill I want to refer, firstly, to the general context of Australian overseas aid and then to make some suggestions regarding the provisions of the Bill. I welcome the Bill. It was originally announced in August last year by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) and now at last has come to legislative form. It is one measure of the Commonwealth Government over the last couple of years which all Australians can welcome and support as an important aspect of the development of our overseas aid effort. I think that effort is not great enough. Parliament should encourage the Government to go more quickly towards the goal that the Government has set itself-spending 0.7 per cent of our gross national product on overseas aid programs. That figure is not as high as I would like it to be. As I have urged in a number of forums, we might exceed that figure so that it is one per cent of gross national product by our bicentennial year, 1988. I take the opportunity of commending again to the Government and to members of the Senate the thought that , in 1988 when we look back at 200 years of our life as a nation, we ought to look outside to see the direct development assistance that we give to our neighbours. It would certainly be magnificent if we were to achieve the spending of one per cent of our gross national product on overseas development assistance .

SPEECH.PARA: Another important step towards this objective was made by the Government in the last Budget when it applied an extra $100m to overseas development assistance. That was an increase of 18 per cent, but it lifted the level of overseas aid only from 0.43 per cent to 0.45 per cent of GNP. This did not reach the 0.6 per cent that was reached in the mid-1970s, when I must admit that gross national product slumped somewhat. Nevertheless, a very substantial standard was arrived at then which we still have not got back to. I am not yet convinced that there is under way in Australia a momentum which will allow us to reach within the next few years the 0.7 per cent goal that the Australian Government has supported and made its own.

Another step that the Government took in the previous Budget was to allow tax deductibility for private overseas aid contributions within very minimal and sensible guidelines. Ordinary Australians giving money to a number of overseas aid funds-about 20 at the moment-are being encouraged in that giving by tax deductibility. These several steps are going in the right direction, as is the present Bill which seeks to establish the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research. I understand that the Centre, when it is fully developed in the coming year, will have some $20m applied to it. I very much welcome all these steps, and I believe we must do more.

I should refer to the incoherent but too often expressed criticisms of Australian overseas aid involvement. Those criticisms are expressed sometimes by State members of parliament and isolationist Australians. They try to justify their criticism of the extent of Australian overseas aid by saying that we should first help those in need at home. Of course we should have thoroughgoing policies which help the needy in Australia and which help various institutions to develop themselves along good lines. But that should in no way distract us from helping our neighbours, particularly those countries in the Pacific and South East Asia that are so close to our land.

Others argue that overseas aid is distorted in some foreign countries, leading to accretions by the already wealthy middle man or commercial manager, the urban elites, and that our aid does not lead to real prosperity for the ordinary families of developing countries. There is some substance in that criticism but I am convinced that the Australian Development Assistance Bureau is very vigilant and seeks to ensure that our aid is of a kind that cannot easily be so diverted and distorted. Anyone who claims seriously that the ADAB budget of some $600m is other than to a very small extent so distorted shows that he has not informed himself of the substance of the programs that ADAB is involved with in various countries and the links with which those programs are monitored.

A third argument against overseas aid which I believe should be entirely resisted is that put forward in the last year or so, too vocally, by some very right wing activists in Australia who argue that the very notion of international co-operation and international development, of Australia being involved with other countries in their development, is somehow on a slippery slope towards a centralised world government; that somehow, by fanciful argument , the United Nations would become a powerful overriding body interfering with, indeed subverting, the sovereignty of national governments. I regard those kinds of arguments as nonsense, as emotive, and as lacking proper information, but having the unfortunate effect of distracting some Australians from a full-bodied support for the kinds of statements that the Commonwealth Government has made, for example at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting, about North-South relations, about exploring in dialogue from developed and developing countries the best steps towards developing countries being involved in more growth. These three types of arguments against overseas aid programs I believe should be resisted and argued against not only in this Parliament but also in the community. That much more vocal group in the community that is calling for an increased overseas aid effort should see more of a response from the Commonwealth Government through increased overseas aid votes.

I now refer directly to the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research Bill 1982 and make some suggestions about the context in which it will operate. Other honourable senators in this debate have referred to the importance of food aid and the Australian record in being of assistance in helping developing countries to meet their own food needs, to be nutritionally self-sufficient as the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) termed it in her second reading speech in the Senate. The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organisation and the World Food Program are both substantially supported by Australia, as is the Consultative Group for International Agriculture Research which, since 1971, has been an important focus of the international community's encouragement for research and agriculture.

When I was a student in the 1960s, and subsequently in the 1970s, I had the opportunity to visit nearly all of the countries in Asia, especially our near neighbours in South East Asia and the Pacific, and to observe over a 17-year period a number of developments related to agriculture and increasing prosperity in those countries. I look back mostly with pride, in a quiet way, at the style of Australian support in our region. I certainly commend that. I remember reading as a teenager a book written by Lederer and Burdick called The Ugly American which argued that somewhat grandiose, heavy-spending, imperialist assistance, however well intentioned from legislatures, was subverted on the way and was used in fact for directly political purposes, for international relations to serve the home country. I do not see that ugly face directly associated with the Australian development program in neighbouring countries. It has not been my observation in the countries near us. There were aspects, perhaps in those years, of a somewhat ugly Australian face and to the extent that there was I urge that the lessons of that era in the early 1960s be continually before us and that we avoid those dangers.

It is for that reason that I urge that whilst this Bill is not a cure-all but is specifically setting up a mechanism for encouraging international agricultural research and needs to be complemented by the other programs of the Australian Development Assistance Bureau, nevertheless the whole context of food production in a developing country and bringing to effect the fruits of new technology and better agricultural research is not, I believe, fully successful in meeting a nutritional self-sufficiency goal for that developing country. I believe that the food output in a country should fill the food needs of that country; but more than that I want to draw attention to the chain of production involved in the growing and distribution of food and the arrangements for this.

By a chain of production I mean that an ordinary farmer, or a group of ordinary farmers, may apply a superior seed with fertilisers in a new way by techniques that are newly taught to them as a result of agricultural research. They will go on perhaps to use their land more effectively and to have an increased productivity from the land. That crop will then go to the city where it may be distributed throughout the country. It will be bought and sold perhaps two or three times in the process of commercial sale and distribution. In some countries that produce such bumper crops the superior crop is sold and, by means of the money earned, other foods are consumed within the country. But too often over the last 20 years it has been the case in developing countries that the profits from such bumper crops, the profits of that higher productivity, have accrued to the urban commercial elite. Too rarely has the productivity increase led to an advanced standard of living for ordinary farmers and ordinary families in the country. So I believe that we must address ourselves to the full chain of production in applying these agricultural research improvements.

I have visited Thailand a number of times, particularly in the last couple of years. Partly through Thai politicians visiting this country and my visiting Thailand I have developed a particular friendship for Senator Sukum Thirawat, a leading senator in the parliament in Thailand. He was the director of the Department of Agriculture in Thailand throughout most of the 1950s. He came to Australia for some months in the early 1950s to look at our forestry production. He went back to Thailand and applied the knowledge he had gained. The eucalypts that grow in Thailand are, in large measure, the fruit of his observations and activities. He also became very aware of the improved technology and the lessons to be learnt from modern agricultural research. As director of the Department of Agriculture he sought to see these lessons taught in his country. After a considerable period, after 30 years of seeing these steps being implemented and these lessons being taught, his unfortunate observation is that the standard of living of the ordinary Thai farmer has been improved only marginally and that the profits involved in the increased productivity within Thailand have accrued too often to the commercial middle people in the city of Bangkok. He has, I believe, a very stable grasp of the experience to be had in this area.

I believe that the Australian Development Assistance Bureau will, in other matters such as training and in extension programs of the results of this research that ACIAR will come to develop, go on to direct its attention very closely to this suggestion that I am making so that we will address ourselves to the full chain of production and ensure, in co-operation with the leaders of developing countries, that there is a real benefit in standard of living improvments for the ordinary people, the ordinary farmers who will apply the fruits of this research.

Finally, I refer to two provisions of the Bill, relating to the Policy Advisory Council and the nature of the research programs to be undertaken. In setting up the Centre, the Bill rules out the possibility of duplicating the research resources that already exist in Australia. I commend the Bill for that. We know that the Waite Institute at the University of Adelaide has a high reputation internationally for its agricultural research. Over 30 years it has given many thousands of students in agriculture post graduate training to the benefit of their countries. That body of expertise will, I believe, be drawn upon by the Centre for research programs. Similarly, I refer to the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation's dry land farming research being conducted in the Northern Territory. This is another good example of the resources already existing in Australia which may, along with overseas institutions, be drawn in by the Centre in the development of programs.

Another important provision of the Bill relates to the Policy Advisory Council. The Bill provides that this Council will include representatives of developed and developing countries' expertise. The Government, very happily, has already announced that the president of the interim advisory council will be Sir John Crawford who has unrivalled expertise and leadership in these matters in Australia. He is equal to the best in the world. The fact that his experience will be available to this Advisory Council in its initial stages is, I believe, of great benefit for the Centre. The representatives from developed and developing countries-particularly developing countries-will have a very important part in defining, in dialogue with others involved in the Centre, the projects of importance to them. Australia will, in that way, be able to directly respond to the needs of our neighbours.

Australia gives aid to about 80 countries throughout the world but the majority of our development assistance aid goes to our own region. I support that emphasis. Two years ago the Pacific countries received $28m. This was spread among about a dozen countries. The five member countries of the Association of South East Asian Nations received some $60m of aid. Papua New Guinea, the country with which Australia has a particular relationship, received $235m in aid. These are three items out of a total of $550m in aid which goes to some 80 countries. Whilst we should give specific development assistance to countries in the Middle East, and notably in Africa, in ways to which earlier speakers in this debate have referred, I believe that we should retain the emphasis on concentrating our development assistance aid in South East Asia and the Pacific. With those observations I warmly commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Primmer Sen C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I approach the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research Bill with great trepidation. Quite frankly, I am baffled by what we in Australia hope to achieve from it. The aim of the Bill is to establish this Centre which will have the function of mobilising and expanding Australia's research capacity so as to assist developing countries in agricultural and related areas and to develop an expanded, better co-ordinated and more identifiable Australian effort aimed at achieving multinational self- sufficiency in developing countries. Clause 5 (1) (a) (i) of the Bill states that one of the functions of the Centre will be to identify the agricultural problems of developing countries. We in Australia have been in this act for quite some time. It seems to me that we should know of the problems that exist. I suggest that there are thousands of papers lying about the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, universities and other institutions that identify the agricultural problems of developing countries if one is looking purely at agriculture. I suggest that it is now time we looked at other problems in developing countries, not specifically agriculture.

SPEECH.PARA: One immediate area that springs to mind is land reform. Do we really think that we, an all-wise nation on this rim of the world, have some ability to go into those countries and assist farmers whose forebears have been farming land for thousands of years? We have been in this country for 200 years and we are ruining it. As I said on a previous occasion, we are allowing it to drift away, blow away, and wash away. We cannot control our own land, yet we have the audacity to go into some other country and try to tell its people how they should run their agricultural enterprises. I suggest, as my deputy leader in the other place said, that if we in Australia want to make any progress in the area of agricultural foreign aid, it is time that we stipulated some measure of land reform in recipient countries before any aid is forthcoming. In my view, that is the greatest downfall and one of the reasons for the bottomless pit of foreign aid from Australia to the underdeveloped world. 'Land to the tiller' is the cry of those in developing countries. It is not being made available, so our money, our research and all the effort we put in is, by and large, going down the drain . Honourable senators should not tell me that the people in those countries do not know how to farm. They were growing rice and all sorts of other things before Captain Cook came to this country. Given the opportunity and the land, I am sure they will surprise even themselves. Clause 5 (1) (a) (ii) of the Bill states:
. . . finding solutions to agricultural problems of developing countries.
I suppose that what I have just said applies to that area also. Clause 5 (1) (b) states:
to commission agricultural research by persons or institutions in Australia ( whether the research is to be conducted in Australia or overseas) in accordance with such programs and policies . . .

I suppose that what I have said applies to that sub-clause also. The research has surely been done. Honourable senators should not tell me that some of our institutions have not by now a fairly good understanding of tropical agriculture . I am sure that they have. It is the political and social conditions in those countries that are inhibiting the further development of the work that has already been done and the practical application of the research work that has been conducted. Extension services and land reform are where the problems lie. They are the areas in which the recipient governments should be working. In my view, the research has been done; it is available. Let those governments get on with the job. Clause 5 (1) (c) states:
to communicate to persons and institutions the results of such agricultural research.

I suggest that that message should be sent to all the institutions in the underdeveloped world if they have not already got it. However, it will be futile for them while their political leaders and other entrepreneurs rip the wealth off the land and from under the soil. A political change has to come about in those countries before we will make any progress. Surely it is time that we started to listen to what is being said about some of our aid projects. The Sydney Morning Herald of 19 February carried the headline 'Australian aid effort under attack'. The article stated:
One of Australia's major foreign aid projects has been criticised by a Freedom From Hunger Campaign official for largely failing to help those it is supposed to reach-the Filipino poor.

Today an article in the Canberra Times was headed 'Concern over project in Philippines'. Again, the message was the same. The aid is not going to the people it is supposed to help. I suggest that this country has led with its heart rather than its head in the area of foreign aid. I suppose any of us can be accused of doing so at times. I suggest further that it is time we stood back and had a fairly cold, hard look at our aid projects around the world and at what we might be trying to do. Undoubtedly, under a scheme such as this, the papers will be written. People will write their doctorates of philosophy on agricultural development in the Third World. I suggest also that those research papers will be about as useful to the farmers in those countries as, to use a farming phrase, tits on a bull. They will be absolutely worthless. The governments concerned, by and large, have no intention whatsoever to lift their poverty-stricken farmers and the rest of their community out of the mire. The governments and their entrepreneurs are making too much money out of the current system under which they operate.

My colleague, Senator Sibraa, mentioned visiting projects in the Middle East. Australian expertise and research has transformed some of those areas. In those projects we have reintroduced to the Middle East such things as subterranean clover. It was brought to Australia from the Mediterranean and it is now being re-exported to that area. The difference, of course, is that the governments of the countries in the Middle East in which those projects are being conducted have the interests of their people at heart. There is a broad consensus on what needs to be done. The expertise that is being provided in Lybia, Iraq and other countries by the state departments is, to some extent, scientific but it is also largely practical. Practical farmers are showing what needs to be done and what can be done. They are not necessarily high flying academics who may have doctorates in agriculture but who do not really understand what grass roots farming is all about.

I will give a couple of examples of that situation which I have seen during my trips abroad. In 1973 or 1974 I was in Pakistan with an Australian delegation visiting a dairy farm, a project that was being jointly financed, from memory, by both the Australian and New Zealand governments. The land had been taken from the peasant farmers who had been given compensation and sent down the road with their buffalo and everything they owned. In 1969 the then Prime Minister, Mr McMahon visited Pakistan and promised the 100 Illawarra shorthorn cattle. They were duly sent and were going quite well until the farmers who had had their land expropriated started to return because the land they were given in lieu did not seem to be quite as good. They missed their aunts and uncles and community groups. Of course, when they came back they brought their buffalo. The buffalo rubbed necks through the fences with the Australian cattle. Before the people running the farm knew where they were, the Australian cattle were dying like flies due to buffalo tick. When I suggested to the people in charge of the project that perhaps the wisest thing to do would be to double fence the farm or carry out a weekly or three weekly campaign of dipping or spraying the cattle for tick, all the poor souls could do was scratch the dirt and remain mute. It seemed to me that that project was falling down because of the lack of even one practical, practising Australian farmer who could have fingered the problem straight away. All the scientific experts in the world were available but the project was falling apart.

I have spoken in this place before of the project in Bogor in Indonesia, just out of Jakarta where the elite live and go for their weekends because it has a nice dry climate. The Australian Government has spent $12m there on an animal research project. We were taken through it and shown all the things that the project had achieved by utilising the native species of chooks, ducks, goats, sheep, buffalo and God alone knows what else. I questioned the farmers only in relation to fowls. Egg production had been lifted from about 60 to 160 a year through breeding techniques. The largely Chinese entrepreneurs had moved in, grabbed the technology that was available, built battery cages and were supplying the egg market of Jakarta. The little peasant farmer with his half a dozen hens on which he and his family relied for an existence were now forced to get out of the trade. The green revolution was working in reverse. I think that was spoken about in this place some time this afternoon in relation to the Bill.

I will close by repeating what I said before: I think it is high time that this nation stopped increasing budgets for foreign aid to underdeveloped countries without giving proper consideration to the people of those countries. Rip-off merchants drain the cream from our foreign aid day after day, and if there is any skim milk left on the bottom of the bucket that is what the peasants get. I think we have been conned right, left and centre. To me it is one of the greatest rorts that the Australian taxpayer is providing for at present.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply- This has been an interesting debate on the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research. A number of views have been expressed. There are those honourable senators who see a great benefit resulting from the establishment of the Centre. I think we ought to remind ourselves that Australia is one of the countries in the forefront of agricultural research. If we are to provide aid it should be in the areas in which we are best equipped to do it. The proposed Centre is one area such as that. It has been identified as a means of giving the most appropriate assistance that we are able to give to those countries that can benefit from it.
—Identified by whom?

—Identified by a number of studies and reports. I listened with great interest to what Senator Primmer said. I accept his sincerity in what he said. I think it is arguable what is the best way in which we can assist food security. There is a fundamental need as food security; there is a deficiency of food for mankind in so many countries of the world. Major studies repeatedly show that an institution which can share world research with other countries and which can give assistance of the kind envisaged under this legislation is a very positive step. The Centre has certainly been considered by the Australian Government in that sense. We recognise that food security cannot be achieved simply by developed countries with food surpluses sending their surpluses elsewhere. If the food is given free or on concessional terms that is not the way in which to guarantee food security far into the future. It can be best achieved by developing countries themselves producing more.

SPEECH.PARA: I note what Senator Primmer said about peasants and others in developing countries understanding their land and the way in which to develop it. If we are to assist them to produce more we have to find means to reduce the manpower, the land resource and the capital investment required to produce a given quantity of food. Again this can be achieved only by research. I hope the Centre will contribute to that.

The establishment of this Centre will be a means for mobilising Australian expertise and directing it specifically to the needs of developing countries. There are deficiencies in Australia's present system and I think it is time to address some of those. Certainly we spent about $2m on agricultural research under the aid program in 1980-81. But our aid is not strategically focused and depends on ad hoc requests from recipient governments. We found there is no really effective mechanism within Australia for systematically identifying sources of expertise within developing countries which would warrant support. If we are to look for strategic research in industrialised countries we would have to get away from the tendency for that to be concentrated on those agricultural commodities that are important to the economies of the industrialised countries. Consequently the supply of new ideas and techniques specifically related to commodities such as tropical crops and improved animal production has become a limiting factor in breaking important barriers to increased food production in many of the developing countries. These were factors that weighed very heavily with us when we decided to establish the Centre. Within the Australian and Pacific regions Australia is the only developed industrialised country with universally recognised expertise and experience in many fields of agricultural research in climatic zones relevant to such countries.

There are many reasons why we need to establish the Centre and to establish it in the form we propose. I think some honourable senators have spoken on those matters in their speeches tonight. Suffice it to say that there is presently no way of fully mobilising Australian agricultural research expertise in universities, State departments of agriculture or the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation in support of agricultural development in developing countries. These institutions, irrespective of any amendments to their charter which sought to accommodate developing-country needs, would continue to give first priority to their in-Australia activities. This Centre will need guidance as to research priorities and the means of meeting them. The high level Advisory Council will be one way of assisting it to do that as effectively as possible. I think everyone is aware from the Bill itself of the way in which that Council will be constituted and the role it will play.

Senator Sibraa questioned whether there would be an overlap, whether this Centre would be similar to an institution such as the International Centre for Tropical Agriculture in Nigeria. I point out to him that the Centre will not resemble that Institute of the Consulative Group on International Agricultural Research. It will not have its own research capacity. It will consist of a small secretariat to contract research to existing institutions or to individuals. As we know and will discuss with the amendments to be moved this Bill includes a twilight provision which provides for the review of the Centre in the tenth year and cessation after 12 years unless the Government introduces further legislation. With those comments I commend the Bill to the Senate. I look forward to the work that it will be able to do to assist in the developing countries with food security.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is not able to accept the amendment that has been moved by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Button) on behalf of the Opposition. We are not rejecting it merely because is seeks a change in the timing for review or anything of that sort. But the provisions in the legislation relating to the term of office of the director, the timing of the review and the expiration of the legislation at seven, 10 and 12 years respectively, have been decided upon only after the most careful consideration. Perhaps I should explain why we selected those three periods. After seeking expert advice the Government considered the initial term of up to seven years as the most appropriate for two reasons. Firstly, reasonable tenure was considered to be essential to attract the very best people in the field for the position and, secondly, it will provide the first director with sufficient time to establish the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research and to have it in full operation, bearing in mind the lead times involved in agricultural research, before his appointment expires. If there is a change of director after seven years the next critical date is that relating to the review process which, under the legislation, will be 10 years. This was very deliberately chosen to give a new director three years to make his mark on the organisation and to implement new policies before the review was undertaken. There would then be two years in which to conduct the review and, depending upon the result, adequate time in which to prepare new legislation or, if the review came to the conclusion that the legislation should not be renewed, adequate time in which to wind down the activities of the Centre.

SPEECH.PARA: It will therefore be seen that all the periods chosen by the Government form part of a carefully related and integrated package. If Senator Button who is proposing this amendment is basing it on the same premise-he has proposed periods of eight years and so on-the Government believes strongly that the ability of the Centre to achieve the objectives as laid down in this legislation would be seriously impaired by that time- table and that it would be difficult to attract a director of the highest calibre. Under the timetable proposed by the Opposition's amendment a director appointed for seven years would find himself in the position of having his administration reviewed when nearing the end of his appointment. This in itself would not be impossible but, in conjunction with the proposed sunset period of eight years, could lead to a ridiculous situation. The review would take some time-perhaps a year-and, depending on the recommendations of the review an incoming director could immediately after taking up his position be faced with major changes to the operation of the Centre or even closure during what could be his single year of office.

A further point which must be taken into account to ensure the effective operation of the Centre is that agricultural research by its very nature is long term, and in most cases one is looking at a lead time of three years to four years from the commencement of the research project until one obtains results which can be translated into practical field action. The timetable proposed in the amendment moved by the Opposition does not take into account this very important consideration. As I have explained, the legislation has been drafted specifically to cover this aspect. For those reasons the Government is not able to accept the amendment moved by the Leader of the Opposition.

That the amendment (Senator Button's) be agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —This legislation replaces a means of stabilising prices for dried sultanas which lapsed a couple of years ago. The old mechanism for stabilising prices was the stabilisation scheme into which payments were made by growers in years of relatively high prices and withdrawn in years of relatively low prices. Frequently, additional contributions from general revenue were made into the fund. Such stabilisation arrangements were common for a number of agricultural products at the time. The Dried Sultana Production Underwriting Bill now before the Senate replaces that means of price stabilisation and introduces what is effectively a three-year moving average, guaranteeing producers 90 per cent of actual market returns for that three-year moving average with this one qualification: That the price for one of the three years in question which comprise the moving average is the estimate for the current season, to be determined by the Minister in consultation with the Bureau of Agricultural Economics. This type of legislation follows the trend to move away from guaranteed prices determined in an overtly arbitrary way, or by some bogus formula, to a market related price, albeit time lodged. The Opposition supports the Bill on those grounds.

SPEECH.PARA: As I mentioned earlier, this is not the first agricultural product which has had its market arrangements changed in this way. Like most enlightened trends in agricultural policy, this trend was first established by the Labor Government in 1974 with the wheat marketing legislation of that year. It is probable that this is a very favourable time for the industry to be introducing such legislation because in recent years prices have been significantly higher than trend prices. Therefore the effect of those high prices of the past two years will tend to write up the underwritten price for the next two years. There is likely to be considerable benefit to the industry. It is certainly a much more favourable time to introduce it now after a couple of years of high prices than a couple of years of low prices. Indeed, because of a very large crop, I understand, in Greece last year and probably in Turkey and Greece's entry into the European Economic Community, it is probable that world market prices will be somewhat lower over the next year or two than they have been in the previous year or two, Greece having been incorporated under the umbrella of the Common Agricultural Policy.

The Common Agricultural Policy is the subject of a good deal of cant and humbug , particularly by the National Country Party Ministers of this Government who deplore the type of agricultural policies in Europe which they themselves implement in Australia. One example-a small example but an ironic example, given the timing-was the move by the Government, reacting to pressure from a tiny but rather noisy minority of canned ham producers on 1 May last year, the day after the so-called razor gang report was delivered. We had this new era of small government when, under pressure from the National Country Party, the Government moved to restrict the piddling quantity of canned ham imports and held them at their pre-existing levels. We are accustomed to hearing that sort of cant and humbug from the National Country Party. That cant and humbug was carried to a new high or a new low, however one likes to look at it, in the last couple of days with whines and whinges from the Leader of the National Country Party, Mr Anthony, about alleged misuse of parliamentary privilege to denigrate or make allegations against members of parliament without corroboration, without proof and without substantial evidence.

I note that the party colleague of Mr Anthony, the Premier of Queensland, called a special sitting of the Queensland Parliament in November 1975 to announce that he had documentary evidence to show that Ministers of the Whitlam Government received kick-backs on overseas loans. No evidence was produced on that occasion. The matter was never mentioned by Mr Bjelke-Petersen again. Mr Anthony managed to swallow his scruples on that occasion and made absolutely no protest against Mr Bjelke-Petersen's typically outrageous action. He sat back and basked in the electorate and collected the electoral benefits of that outrageous action.

The cost of this scheme cannot be estimated with any certainty or any precision because it involves assumptions about future market prices. It is, however, I expect, unlikely to be above $5m per year; that is, about 10 per cent of the normal value of production. That would be the highest year. It is possible that there may be no cost to revenue. At that level it would be a 10 per cent degree of price support in the most unfavourable years. This is not, by horticultural standards at least, a very high level of government support, although indirect subsidies are paid to this industry in the form of underpriced irrigation water and an external diseconomy arising from the industry in the form of saline pollution, to a limited extent, of land and, to a greater extent, the Murray Valley. It is, however, relatively efficient by horticultural industry standards .

There is certainly a great deal more justification for the expenditure of a limited amount of public funds in this area than there is for the scandalous rorts, for example, enacted by the Fraser Government for the benefit, among others, of Pitt Street farmers and, in particular, for that group of particularly notable Pitt Street farmers who, as Sentor Sibraa reminds me, compromise about half the present Federal Cabinet.

One of these taxation rorts, for example, enables them to lend $10,000 for one year, to borrow $15,000 for two years and to pick up a $4,500 cash bonus in the process, half of which is tax free. That is a rort which is available to any person with a pie off-farm income and substantial farming interests, a category which includes half of the Fraser Cabinet. There is absolutely no justification for that scandalous abuse of the income equalisation deposit scheme, a scheme which, while justified in itself with proper rules and proper conditions, has been abused by the Government for the potential benefit of half its members and for the potential benefit of a number of other wealthy Pitt Street Farmers. That comprises a scandalous misuse of public funds tantamount almost to a theft.
