TALK.START.PARA: —I crave the indulgence of the Senate. The speech which I wish to make is, in fact, in the nature of a statement as the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operation's. Therefore I crave some indulgence to read my speech. I point out that it has been approved by all honourable members of the Committee; I make it as Chairman of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to make some comments regarding the Dried Sultana Production Underwriting Bill. Initially I wish to say that we do not question that the Australian dried vine fruits industry is, and will continue to be, an important contributor to Australian primary production and to Australia's export earnings. Whether payments of financial aid should be made to an industry is obviously a question of policy for the Government to make, particularly where prevailing circumstances in the market for a particular commodity are unstable or uncertain . It is not our function to comment on such policy decisions.

The Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, as part of its continuing oversight of Commonwealth statutory authorities, has, on several occasions, referred to practical effects of providing equalisation support or other financial support to primary industries, particularly if made through marketing authorities. We are concerned at some of these practical effects on the revenue, the industries involved and how such schemes may affect the proper accountability of authorities to the Parliament. Schemes may be open-ended at their establishment. No definite time period is set for the duration of support and no limit is set on financial commitments. Schemes which start with the intention that they apply to a market that prevails at the time legislation is enacted may end only when producers in an industry become uneconomic, or the entire industry becomes uncompetitive.

We are pleased to see that the Bill contains several provisions which provide a proper basis for avoiding such problems. Clause 3 of the Bill limits the initial operations of the scheme to the selling seasons 1982-85 and is a welcome recognition that legislation may be drafted with the intention that it have a limited life before review as to whether it should be continued. The Standing Committee has discussed such sunset clauses in its various reports and has noted that they may, in appropriate cases-I wish to emphasise the words 'in appropriate cases'-be advantageously used to allow periodic judgment of the effectiveness of such schemes to ensure that they are of positive assistance to the recipients and their continuation is appropriate and warranted.

Clause 7 of the Bill provides that the guaranteed minimum return rate to producers will be set by the Minister and that the return will reflect prevailing world prices for the commodity. It is appropriate that the Minister, under clause 7, sub-clause (4), may have regard to advice from both the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation and, if he so wishes, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics. Giving the Minister the choice does not, in any way, detract from the abilities of the Dried Fruits Corporation, but goes some way to ensure that the Minister not only acts on informed advice from the industry but also receives objective advice on market conditions.

Clause 15 provides the Minister with the power to direct the Dried Fruits Corporation with respect to minimum export prices for dried sultanas. This is an important power because it is the floor price which determines the underwriting payments that are to be made. As the Standing Committee has pointed out in the past, legislation can and should be drafted so as to avoid any confusion as to where responsibility for policy decisions and decisions affecting the administration of the statutory authority lies. When a Minister has the power to direct statutory authorities, as is provided in clause 15 in this Bill, particularly with regard to price support, the Minister's involvement in such policy formulation should be disclosed to the Parliament and through the Parliament to the people.

The powers which I have mentioned relate to only two aspects of the mechanism for fixing the return under this scheme. In addition to clause 7 and 15 of the Bill the Minister is required by other provisions to fix the average return rate for a season, the reduction factor for a season's crop, payment of advances on account of underwriting payments and the payment of underwriting payments to the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation for distribution to growers. I wish to stress the point that decisions will be required from the Minister on a range of matters under this legislation. The Standing Committee's experience suggests emphatically that there will be little, if any, reporting to this Parliament of occasions on which the Minister actually exercises these powers and whether it is on advice from his Department, the Dried Fruit Corporation, or, in the case of the guaranteed minimum return, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics. Only when the details of such decision making are routinely reported to Parliament can authorities and Ministers be considered properly accountable for their actions.

As I have stated, the Committee does not question the principle of support which will be provided by the Bill or the way in which it is to be paid. However , we are particularly aware that members of this Parliament are criticised for failing to comment upon legislation of this sort when it is first enacted and for having the temerity to question the effectiveness or economic wisdom of underwriting schemes when some of the problems to which I have adverted appear at a later date. In this regard I note also that the Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills has studied the Bill and drawn the Senate's attention to aspects of the Bill which, whilst outside the terms of reference of the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, are most certainly appropriate for consideration by the Senate when debating the Bill.

It should finally be recalled that the quid pro quo for parliamentary and public support of underwriting schemes must always be complete and regular accountability to the Parliament. As the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Nixon , said when opening the Agricultural Outlook Conference on 26 January 1982:

Statutory authorities are a vital part of the marketing of Australian primary products. They must be given as much commercial independence as possible, so they can carry out their job efficiently and return maximum prices to farmers. However, they must also properly account to the Parliament that created them, and to the industries that pay for them.
We would happily adopt the words used by the Minister. Accountability is the quid pro quo for the passage of this legislation through this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise two items in relation to the Dried Sultana Production Underwriting Bill before the Senate tonight. One item deals with the substance of the Bill itself; that is, the provision to underwrite arrangements to support returns to producers of dried sultana grapes in the seasons from 1982 to 1986. The arrangement that is before us in the Bill has the total support of the industry. I believe that this is an appropriate Bill to be brought forward in the current circumstances.

SPEECH.PARA: The major problems, of course, with the industry are probably only emerging and arise basically from movements outside Australia and over which Australia has no control. I refer here to Greece's entrance into the European Economic Community, the fact that the Northern Hemisphere has recently had excellent sultana crops and that in Greece the crop is likely to increase from 65,000 tonnes to 100,000 tonnes and the fact that Greece will be within the operation of the EEC where prices are likely to be substantially lower than those currently offered on the world market. Indeed, on available figures it would seem that an EEC price equivalent may be $1,250 a tonne as against the average price that Australia has been able to receive since 1978 of $1,650 a tonne. I think those price differentials really suggest that we are likely to be heading into very difficult times with this industry.

However, the Australian Democrats do not take the sort of approach that is currently being taken by the National Country Party. We believe that the EEC is a fact of life and that it is necessary to face up to the fact that the EEC exists and that it has certain policies. It is necessary for the Australian Government to take those facts into account and seek to arrange the industry support within Australia as best it can to meet future contingencies. Therefore, we support wholeheartedly the move that the Government has made in this regard. I believe that the industry itself will be quite thankful to the Government for this move.

I originally proposed to move three amendments at the Committee stage. However, I will not now be moving amendment No. 1 standing in my name but rather only amendments Nos 2 and 3. These amendments are prompted by the appearance on the legislative scene of the innovative Senate Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills. I believe that this is the first time that the Senate has had the chance to debate a Bill that has had comments made upon it by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. It is my intention to read closely the reports in the areas with which I normally deal as those reports come from the Scrutiny of Bills Committee , and where they are reasonable and point to deficiencies in drafting or undue trespass on the personal rights and liberties of Australian citizens we will be moving amendments to Bills in accordance with the items raised by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. I give notice to the Senate that in future that will be our position with Bills.

The particular clauses that have been raised, are relatively simple clauses. The problems, of course, in at least one of those are fairly immense. It is really very difficult in a reasonable amendment to such a Bill to try to solve some of the types of problems that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee has raised. I point in particular to the problem raised in relation to the onus of proof. Fairly obviously, it is not possible to come to grips in this Bill with a problem which has caused considerable difficulty for some time. I refer the Senate to the sixty-sixth report of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. On page 6, item 24, the Committee recommended that the matter of statutory provisions imposing burdens of proof be referred to the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is being done at present.

—That particular item is currently before that Committee and is being studied. I raise that point because the technicalities of that area are obviously extremely complex. It is not possible to meet those matters head on in a Bill dealing with dried sultana production underwriting. We await, as I am sure other senators do, with some anticipation the result of the deliberations of the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs so that future Bills of this kind, when they come before the Senate, might be dealt with more adequately.

SPEECH.PARA: The other two clauses of the Bill that were raised by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee are clause 16 (3), which relates to the requirement to furnish information that may be incriminating, and clause 17, which relates to supplying information to a variety of organisations. The obligation seems to be unduly harsh. It would seem more simple if a citizen were required merely to report to one body, that is the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation, and if the Corporation were allowed to move further on. I want to raise specific items in the Committee stage but at this time I point to the fact that in future we will be raising those items. The time that might be available for that depends to a great extent on the ability of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee to bring forward the results of its deliberations. The Committee has done, I believe, an excellent job so far but, of course, once its report is published it is then necessary for senators to address themselves to that report and to the Bills before them and in their deliberations to make decisions in relation to the amendments that they might wish to bring forward. Therefore, the time that is available may not be great. The Australian Democrats will endeavour to give as much lead time as possible but this is not always possible, given the necessity to wait on the Scrutiny of Bills Committee and then to read its report in terms of the legislation in its totality. I would like to take this opportunity on behalf of the Australian Democrats to commend the work that is currently being done by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. We believe it has already shown itself to be an extremely valuable addition to the legislative arm of the Senate in its review capacity. We will be looking forward to the types of recommendations made by this Committee being addressed not necessarily only in the Senate but also in the drafting stages of future Bills so that ultimately the Scrutiny of Bills Committee will have fewer tasks to perform.

SPEECH.PARA: The second matter raised by the Committee concerned sub-clause (3) of clause 16 , which contains a not uncommon provision that persons may be required to furnish information notwithstanding that it might be incriminating. This provision alters the Commonwealth's situation. It is generally provided in such clauses that such furnished information is not to be admissible in evidence against the person in proceedings other than proceedings for an offence under the particular section. Of course, this is a restriction on the Commonwealth's position and the objections that people can make, but it cannot be said to be a unique provision. It has been used in a number of other circumstances, including legislation regarding primary products such as we have before us tonight. I do not think there is a practical problem in that respect. The rest of the amendment is based on misapprehension. I suggest to Senator Macklin that he might even consider withdrawing this amendment. The problem which he mentioned does not arise if one looks at the wording of the clause. The Bill requires a person who has received payment which is in excess of the amount payable to him to inform the Dried Fruits Corporation or, in any other case, the Department of Primary Industry. That provision is there because if one looks at the earlier parts of the Bill, in particular at clause 13 (4), it becomes readily apparent that, under the Bill, payments may be made to growers by the Corporation but they may be also made by the Commonwealth through a department. Where the Corporation is not involved in the payment, it would appear to be inappropriate to go to the Corporation in respect of the overpayment. The clause requires the grower to advise the Corporation if the Corporation is the body which made the payment or, if that is not the case, the Department which is charged with the responsibility of administering the Act, which is the alternative body which will, in that case, have made the payment. SPEECH.PARA: I certainly appreciate the role of the new Senate Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills in drawing to the attention of the Senate and to this Committee the possibility that there are clauses which need careful consideration to make sure that we are not unduly trespassing on rights and liberties. TALK.START.PARA: —On reflection I think I may have been wrong in assuming that this amendment, if it had been carried, would have deleted the penalty, because although it says 'Leave out all words after '' inform'' ' it does also refer to lines 7 and 12, and the penalty provision appears in line 13. However, there is no real problem with the 'Department' referred to in this sub-clause; the department is the Department of Primary Industry, under present administrative arrangements. Whilst one could not reasonably expect every sultana producer to know that, if a payment has been received by someone other than from the Dried Fruits Corporation it will have been paid by some department, with an accompanying letter. So, in practice, I do not think there is any problem for a grower in identifying the authority to which he is obliged by this clause, to report an overpayment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the explanation given by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) is reasonable. However, even on his words, there is a possibility of a conjunctive meaning of the word 'or'. However, I take the point raised by the Minister and by Senator Walsh that, in these circumstances, in terms of payment, it is likely that such confusion would not arise. I am satisfied with the explanation which the Minister has given and I seek leave to withdraw the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; amendment withdrawn.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will make a brief comment. I did not mean, in any sense, to be offensive in suggesting that the amendment be withdrawn. If the Senate is to approach these matters in the spirit in which the committee was established, I think we can agree that, after perusal, the proposal is not objectionable and we ought to proceed on that basis. But I thank the Senate for its courtesy in the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: — There is another point. I do not wish to make it the subject of an amendment but I would like to draw attention to it. I refer to clause 17 (1) which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: A person who receives, in respect of an underwriting payment, a payment that, to his knowledge, is not payable to him, or exceeds the amount payable to him, shall, as soon as practicable, inform-
(a) . . . the Corporation: or
(b) in any other case-the Department . . .

It does not specify in what way they shall inform. One of the problems which I am sure all honourable members of Parliament have experienced is the problem that arises where somebody rings up or, by some other means, calls in and provides information to a department and the recording system is inadequate to the task. Subsequently there is a dispute. This is something which arises with monotonous regularity in relation to the social security area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—Well, not in the time of the present Minister, perhaps. But it is a problem. I think that it would be best overcome if, in relation to this, people considering what is required were to add, themselves, the words 'in writing'. Thus people would be able to ensure that they have some proof of having provided the information. Perhaps consideration could be given by both the Scrutiny of Bills Committee and the Parliamentary Draftsman to any such requirement as this in future being required to be in writing or by some other documentary or recorded means. This could overcome a problem which can be most unfortunate if someone has genuinely done what they were required to do but is unable to prove it because it was not drawn to their attention that, for their own sake, they should have done it in such a way that they could prove compliance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to prolong debate on the matter but I want to make a brief comment on what Senator Rae said. I think that, as a counsel of prudence, what Senator Rae said is absolutely correct. Where there is something like an overpayment, a risk of penalty and an allegation of dishonesty, clearly it would be sensible to make notification in writing. At the same time, I think the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, or, indeed, the Government when looking at these matters, needs to be conscious of the fact that if one put in the requirement of notice 'in writing', one would, indeed, be adding another potential hurdle to a person who might be acting quite innocently. In other words, there are a great number of informal dealings which do successfully handle these matters. Somebody might well ring up or talk to the inspector to do something which he thought put him in the clear, not having a copy of the statute to hand and not understanding that there was a formal requirement to do it in writing. So I think it is a two-edged sword. I am not trying to be definitive or final in my comment. I merely throw that in as something which needs to be carefully considered if we were to pick up the general suggestion made by Senator Rae.
—It is for that sort of reason that I do not suggest an amendment at this stage.
—No. I think one would need to look at that very carefully. But I certainly agree that, as a counsel of prudence, that is something that I would recommend to anybody in this situation.

DEBATE.TITLE: FAMILY LAW AMENDMENT BILL 1981MAINTENANCE ORDERS (COMMONWEALTH OFFICERS) AMENDMENT BILL 1981MIGRATION AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 October 1981, on motion by Senator Durack:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —With the usual unexpectedness with which things that have been hanging around for a long while come upon us, I find myself at 10 .15 on a Tuesday night opening the debate on what will be a fairly significant occasion for this Parliament-the consideration of the first major set of amendments to what on any view is a major piece of legislation. The Family Law Act is a major Act. This amending legislation is very important, confronting as it does some quite difficult issues. I for one welcome its advent. The Family Law Act 1975 was certainly one of the enduring legacies of the Murphy Attorney- Generalship. It is important, if it is to go on being enduring, that its more important elements be kept constantly under review and adapted to achieve maximum public benefit in a situation of manifestly changing social conditions. The only note of regret that I sound at the outset, in general terms, is that that process of review has not been more constant and speedier than on this occasion. Certainly, the process by which this legislation has wended its weary way into the parliament would set no world speed record.

SPEECH.PARA: The basic substance of the Bill derives from recommendations of the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act which was established in September 1978. It reported in July 1980, reporting to the Parliament formally in August of that year. The response of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) to the Joint Select Committee's report came 14 months later in October 1981. It was not until late November last year that the Bill was finally introduced into the Parliament. Moreover, the Bill, in the form in which it appears before us, does not by any means fully encompass the recommendations of the Joint Select Committee. Not only have a number of its recommendations been explicitly rejected by the Attorney, in some instances for reasons that are supportable and are backed by the views of the Family Law Council, but also a number of proposals, extraordinary as it sounds after the time lapse, have been deferred. It is a matter of some regret to those of us who are anxious to see a workable, streamlined, efficient, equitable system of family law that the process somehow has not been able to be more expeditiously conducted.

The debate on the Family Law Amendment Bill is not the occasion to reopen the whole tortured and ultimately unproductive debate about the very foundations of the Family Law Act; that is, questions about the ground of divorce, the length of separation required to show the breakdown of the marriage relationship and the related question of whether the Family Law Act has increased or, as I believe, has had no effect on the rate of marriage breakdown and divorce. There are various reasons why that debate should not be reopened, although I doubt whether the indefatigable campaigners, in this chamber and elsewhere, for a return to divorce based on fault will be able to exercise the necessary self- restraint.

The reasons I call in aid are these: In the first place, it is evident that viewpoints on these fundamental issues about family law are ultimately irreconcilable, based as they are very often on deeply rooted moral principles verging on articles of faith-jumps of faith-which do not always allow for parallel intellectual discourse. Secondly, the debate was a very extended one in 1974 and 1975 within this Parliament as it was in the community as a whole. There is simply no evidence of any significant change in relevant circumstances or of any demand in the community at large which would warrant a further airing of these so-called big issues. Thirdly, it must be said that the Joint Select Committee carefully considered the issues of divorce and separation which I have mentioned. After hearing very lengthy and substantial evidence from a number of conflicting viewpoints, including, of course, the viewpoint of Senator Martyr who was a member of the Joint Select Committee, it recommended that there be no change to the ground of divorce or the separation period.

I believe-although it is false hope, no doubt-that it is inappropriate for us to spend very much time going over well-trodden, familiar and ultimately unproductive ground of this kind. I also believe we should resist attempts to turn the so-called divorce by post amendment-which I will come back to in a moment-into a vehicle for wide-ranging debate on the fundamental character of our family law system. It is a much overrated change in terms of its inherent significance and certainly does not go, in my belief, to the fundamentals of the Family Law Act. No doubt, though, we will all have much more to say on this subject in the context particularly of the Committee stage.

I state for the record that I personally-in a sense we are all making personal statements in considering legislation of this kind, it being a free debate and a free vote issue-firmly support the basic principles and philosophy of the Family Law Act. In particular I support its removal of the concept of matrimonial fault , thereby ending the humiliation, bitterness and hypocrisy associated with attempts to show who was the so-called guilty party. Those advances and the establishment of the single ground, no fault divorce, I believe, must on no account be jeopardised. I take the view that, free from the burden of attributing fault, the Family Court can now concentrate on being satisfied as to the fact of marriage breakdown-a much simpler endeavour-and on deciding the most equitable distribution of property, the proper level of maintenance and above all, of overwhelming importance, the best possible arrangements for the welfare of any children of the marriage.

Looking in a little more detail at the contents of the Bill, it is to be noted that only 27 out of the 72 recommendations of the Joint Select Commitee on the Family Law Act are implemented wholly or in part by this legislation. Of course, of the remainder of the recommendations quite a number are administrative rather than legislative in character. But it is still the case that a number of recommendations have not been adopted, and either rejected outright or deferred for further consideration. The Attorney-General in his detailed response to the Committee report on 13 October 1981 explained which of those recommendations have been adopted, which have been recommended and why. I note with interest the manifest influence of the Family Law Council-whose deliberations and recommendations are recorded in its fifth annual report-in the Attorney-General' s judgment in this respect.

I will not deal in detail at this stage with the provisions of the Bill except to the extent they are relevant to the more general remarks that I want to make. Of course, there will be, as we all know, a lengthy Committee stage on this measure. I foreshadow that I shall move certain amendments-perhaps six or eight altogether-in particular in areas where recommendations of the Joint Select Committee have been rejected or deferred without what I would consider to be good, clearly articulated reasons.

As a whole, the Bill is a very complicated subject matter. I think the category of things that it deals with are fourfold. In the first place there are matters relating to jurisdiction and standing. The jurisdiction of the Family Court over children and property is significantly expanded. I will say a little more about that in a moment. For really the first time third parties are given standing to bring proceedings in relation to child custody in certain identified circumstances.

Secondly, a number of matters in the Bill deal with administration which I believe, by and large, contribute to the better administration of the Family Court. I refer to provisions relating to open courts, to the publication of proceedings-subject to certain restrictions-to the power of arrest proposed to be attached to injunctions, to the creation of an appeal division in the court, to the provision allowing for non-attendance in future at undefended dissolution proceedings-the so-called divorce by post provision-and the provision for rules- making power to be vested in Family Court judges.

The third general subject matter of the Bill is the welfare of children. There is provision made now for the wishes of children to be considered in all cases, not just the limited class where this applied hitherto. Offences currently in the Migration Act 1958 relating to the removal of children from Australia will now be inserted in the Family Law Act. This is long overdue. The distinction between confidential conferences and counselling reports to the Court which has caused quite a deal of confusion in the past is clarified and that will aid quite considerably the administration of family law as it affects, I believe, the welfare of children. The amendment to the principal Act directs the Court, where an Australian custody order conflicts with a registered foreign custody order, to discharge the Australian order unless the welfare of the child dictates otherwise.

Fourthly and finally the Bill deals with financial proceedings, making provisions for adjournments of significant periods to be granted before orders are finalised so as to enable, in particular, superannuation benefits subsequently accruing to be taken into account. Provision is made for the variation of property orders in circumstances where in the past the rights of the parties have been inflexibly solidified at arguably too early a stage in the dissolution proceedings. There is a clarification of the power to imprison for failure to pay maintenance, which may do something to concentrate the minds of maintenance offenders in that respect.

I turn to some of the more specific matters dealt with in the Bill. Perhaps two of the most significant changes in the Bill involve expansion of the Family Court's jurisdiction based on the extended use of the Commonwealth's constitutional powers in relation to marriage and divorce. There is now provision enabling property proceedings, the first of the two areas in question, to be brought arising out of the marital relationship but in circumstances unrelated to proceedings for dissolution. In other words, property squabbles between married people can now be resolved, if this measure goes through-if it survives any subsequent attack in the High Court-without the necessity for there to be full-blown dissolution proceedings operating simultaneously.

The second of the two areas where jurisdiction is substantially extended relates to children. There is an expansion of the class of children deemed to be children of the marriage, and for the purpose of the Act, to include a number of sub-classes not presently within the jurisdiction of the Family Court at all. In particular, this relates to a child adopted by either party with the consent of the other, a child of either party who is ordinarily a member of the household and a child treated by both parties as a child of their family and who is ordinarily a member of the household. These are all, extraordinary as it sounds, classes of children excluded hitherto from the jurisdiction of the Family Court.

The additional important change in the constitutional area affects standing. There is now to be provision enabling, as I mentioned before, a third party to bring custody in similiar proceedings against one or both of the parties to the marriage. I make it clear that I for one welcome very much the more adventurous use of Commonwealth constitutional power which is inherent in these provisions and which, indeed, is in striking contrast to the very narrow, timid, cautious contractionist effect of the Family Law Amendment Act 1976 which followed the rather disappointingly restricting High Court decision in the case of Russell v. Russell. My party's policy in this area states the objective of the extension of the jurisdiction of the Family Court as being to cover all family law matters. By that we certainly intend a very broad interpretation of the concept of ' families'. That this is the only sensible objective, I suggest, is graphically illustrated by the case of Fountain v. Alexander, the subject of quite a deal of recent publicity, which involved legal action between the foster parents and the natural mother of a 14-year-old boy for the custody of the boy.

Obviously, there is not any time to articulate all the details of this case. The foster parents brought proceedings in the New South Wales Supreme Court, which proceedings were opposed by the natural mother, who argued that the proceedings should be determined by the Family Court. The Commonwealth intervened to remove the case to the High Court, where it argued that the case fell within the jurisdiction of the Family Court. The foster parents were supported by the all too predictable intervention of Queensland, Western Australia and Victoria, who argued strongly that it was a State matter and that the powers of the State court must be maintained. The High Court has reserved its decision on the jurisdiction question and in the meantime the custody of this poor child remains in complete limbo. In conclusion I echo the remarks of Justice Helsham of the New South Wales Supreme Court that this is a disgraceful state for the law to be in.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Refugee and Immigration Policy-Department of Social Security-Trans Australia Airlines-Ansett Transport Industries Ltd-Shipping Company: Charges-Mr Rupert Murdoch: Business Ventures

PROCTEXT.PARA: Refugee and Immigration Policy-Department of Social Security-Trans Australia Airlines-Ansett Transport Industries Ltd-Shipping Company: Charges-Mr Rupert Murdoch: Business Ventures

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want briefly to flesh out certain aspects of the Government's refugee policy. I have a letter from the Area Director of Parramatta office of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, which is in the outer western area of Sydney. I think the Minister has seen a copy of that letter. I seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
12 February 1982
Mrs L. Dregorius,
6/102 Longfield Street,
Cabramatta, N.S.W. 2166
Dear Mrs Dregorius,
I refer to your nomination for entry to Australia of your brother, Wladyslaw Oleszczak.

The nomination has now been forwarded to my office in Paris. This office is not normally advised of the outcome of applications, your nominee should be able to advise you of the result of his application.
If you have any further enquiries please quote 'N81/305402'.
Yours sincerely,
D. CANCERI, for Area Director.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. If, as I said to the Chairman of Estimates Committee D an hour ago, Estimates committees functioned on an ongoing basis I would not be speaking in the adjournment debate. Perhaps one day we will reach a stage where Estimates committees operate all the year round. Notwithstanding the fact that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs ( Mr Macphee) made a statement earlier today in the other place, some concern has been shown by the Polish community about the specific way in which, for various reasons, those people who are not prepared to return to Poland under the present government find themselves in various parts of Europe.

SPEECH.PARA: Considerable publicity has been given to a large number of people in a United Nations refugee camp in Vienna, Austria and another group in Germany. The Minister gave the impression today that some 4,400 refugees were involved and that 1,400 people were designated migrants. In the broad context of the Government's latest utterances I fully subscribe to the view that in some cases when people who purport to be refugees seeking asylum have their credentials examined they do not add up. But in the Polish context the case I have in mind involves a person who surfaced in Paris. The letter that has been incorporated in Hansard is rather impersonal. It states that the nomination for entry to Australia was noted and sent overseas and that it was not the practice of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs necessarily to send feed-back or progress reports to the various regional offices. I know that the Department is in a stage of effecting rigid economies, but immigration is a personal matter, particularly the immigration of refugees.

I speak tonight at the behest of sizable sections of the Polish community in Sydney. We have reached virtually the last quarter of the 1981-82 year and we have yet to complete the 1982-83 period. I am a little concerned by the Minister 's statement. Does it mean that we will take the estimated 4,500 refugees out of the congested areas of Vienna and Berlin? Where do people stand who have surfaced in Paris or at other Australian migration posts in Europe?

I raise this matter based on the well-founded fears of sections of the Polish community in Sydney. I do not ignore the complexities of the problems that beset the Government. Since the early days of the exodus from Vietnam we have had a situation of large numbers of refugees being in Thailand, Malaysia and even Hong Kong. I am not altogether sure whether we work strictly on the basis of when people were registered at respective refugee camps. I am not sure of the relativities. I repeat that I would like informatoin from the Minister as to whether the numbers of people he has given will apply to the year ending 30 June 1982 or whether they will flow on to the year 1982-83. If it is the latter response, the question I ask is whether there will have to be a cut off point or will it be similar to the situation which applied in respect of Vietnam? For example, if a person's identification with the Solidarity movement was such that he would be classified persona non grata if he went back across the borders into Poland, I want to know by which method such an application would be processed.

I repeat that if the Area Director in Parramatta had been more specific I would not necessarily have raised the matter. Leaving aside the Polish intake, there are one or two other countries that come to mind. Honourable senators will be well aware that I am waiting for an answer regarding a group of 50 people from Uruguay who have been placed in a United Nations camp, I think, in Brazil. Those people are waiting to be processed. I am forced to seek some specific response. The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs did give undertakings in relation to people whom he regarded as being subject to duress if they returned to their own country. He spoke about a special humanitarian program. He has emphasised-again, I do not quarrel with the decision-that each case should be taken on its merits.

In relation to the Vietnam situation there was a well orchestrated campaign conducted by people in Australia-I do not question their motives-which tended to ride rough shod over all other groups in Australia which had relatives in countries which were having a fairly torrid time with oppression. I spoke with the Australian Ambassador in Peru when he was in Australia on furlough and there is no question in my mind about the facilities which exist in Lima, Peru. Peru is surrounded by countries, such as Chile, Uruguay, the Argentine and Bolivia, which have military dictatorships. Those countries are similar to Australia in terms of size. People have to travel enormous distances if they wish to go to Peru.

Initially I dealt with the question of Poland. It may be argued that many Latin Americans, particularly if they are politically inclined or political activists, may prefer to remain in that hemisphere in the hope that one day the military dictatorship will disappear and they will go back to an active political life. I did alert the Minister to what I was going to say. I simply ask him whether he is in a position tonight to flesh out the statement made by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Macphee, in another place about the number of Polish people who are escaping from the current extreme trend that has occurred in Poland. I ask whether the people who make application in Paris to come to Australia have as equal an opportunity as those people who happen to be inmates in a United Nations camp in Vienna or West Germany.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly tonight I complete the record concerning the dispute last year beween the Department of Social Security and, in particular, the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) and members of his staff who are members of the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association. Secondly, I draw the attention of the Senate to the sort of behaviour that the Government has been indulging in. With one voice the Government bewails the fact that this country cannot afford increased expenditure-that it must cut back on expenditure-and with another voice it is spending a considerable amount of money on matters that one could hardly think are important.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to raise the matter of one of the great wastes of money by the Government-that is, the $361,790 media attack which was conducted by the Minister, Senator Chaney, on those members of his Department who were in dispute with him. If we add to that the extra moneys which have had to be spent by, in particular, the New South Wales Department of Youth and Community Services and various voluntary agencies in this community, we are talking about considerably over $1m.

Recently we were told by way of answers to questions that the funds which Senator Chaney and his Department spent were obtained from appropriation line No . 590/2/10 which is declared to be for publicity purposes. This was augmented in January this year by drawing on the Advance to the Minister for Finance pending Additional Estimates which, as honorable senators know, cover contingencies not foreseen when the previous Budget was put together.

It is not that no one benefited from this sort of expenditure. We know that one Mr Jonathan Gaul, who is a well-known Liberal Party public relations man, was paid $2,850 for a couple of weeks work during which he gave advice on the exercise in union and Public Service bashing which was conducted by the Minister . He was hired despite the fact that the Minister has at his disposal in the publicity section of his Department 12 public servants who should have been adequate for this sort of work in any circumstances.

Of course, various newspapers and radio stations around the country benefited from this expenditure at the time. As well as the usual newspapers such as the Sydney Morning Herald and the Daily Telegraph in Sydney and the Age and the Sun News Pictorial in Melbourne, daily newspapers in Albury, Bathurst, Broken Hill, Dubbo, Goulburn, Grafton, Lismore, Maitland Murwillumbah, Orange, Tamworth and Wagga Wagga in New South Wales and the Bernie Advocate, Hobart Mercury and the Perth Sunday Independent, benefited from publishing what was almost a saga of advertisements.

TALK.START.PARA: —They left out the Examiner, did they?

—They must have left out the Examiner. I might be able to find it in the list but if it has been left out I am sure that Senator Peter Rae will complain about it afterwards. We had a saga of advertisements, the first being headed 'Message to Social Security Clients'. The next was headed 'A Message to all Pensioners in N.S.W.', and the next 'The Following Message has Been Sent to all Department of Social Security Staff Members in N.S.W. and Vic.'. Then the situation became a little more dramatic when Jonathan Gaul was employed. The next advertisement was headed: 'The Government was Elected/This Union Represents '. Then we had 'An Official Message for Everyone Receiving Pensions and Benefits ' and then another, 'An Official Message for Everyone Receiving Pensions and Benefits'. The final advertisement was appropriately entitled 'Enough's Enough'. I do not know for whom the advertisement headed 'Enough's Enough' was intended, whether it was for the taxpayers of this country or for the people who read the newspapers.

SPEECH.PARA: While this was going on radio stations in New South Wales and Victoria were similarly receiving advertisements justifying the position of the Minister for Social Security. I am sure that honourable senators will remember that bans had been placed in several areas of departmental work in the Department of Social Security to draw attention to the staff shortages which had resulted in low staff morale, staff being exhausted, frustrated clients and general inefficiency within the Department. By last year all these problems had been removed except that in some offices a ban remained on the recovery of overpayments. This was the case at Budget time when it was not foreseen, we were told by the Minister in his answers, that he would go off on an offensive to prevent and to stop the small number of bans which had been applied by the Department. From mid-November until a fortnight before Christmas the Minister, in a great blaze of publicity, went on the rampage. He was standing down staff and we had introduced into the language a new term. People were being CEEPed. The Minister was CEEPing people for further effect, we assume.

TALK.START.PARA: —And de-CEEPed.

—Later, as Senator Coates pointed out, they were de-CEEPed in a de-CEEPing procedure. The results of this little exercise were far more serious for many families. Thousands of people poured into emergency aid offices and came to the counters of the Department of Youth and Community Services particularly in Sydney where over $1m had to be paid out by the New South Wales Government, which had not been a party to Senator Chaney's intemperate decision to mow down his own staff members, to stand down officers in his Department. That half a million dollars, plus hundreds of thousands of dollars from other aid agencies, can be added to the $361,000 propaganda effort, making up the more than $1m that I have suggested was spent on this little episode described by some as Senator Chaney's folly.

SPEECH.PARA: Throughout the entire action in debates in this place, in debates on television and in the news media and in the sorts of advertisements that Senator Chaney was putting out, Senator Chaney pleaded that he had to be tough and that he could not negotiate while bans were on; but wearing his other hat as the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations he admitted in this place on 23 February 1982 that in dealing with Public Service unions while bans are on:
It is normal for discussions to continue aimed at securing a lifting of work bans and limitations in order that the merits of claims may be considered in an atmosphere free of industrial duress.

In practice it is not always possible to totally divorce discussions aimed at removal of all industrial action from consideration of the merits of particular claims that may have given rise to that industrial action.

But the Minister, Senator Chaney, refused to consider the merits of the ACOA claims, and cost the country $1m-I suggest that that is the sum of money that was squandered by his obstinacy-and created difficulties for many of his social security clients.

An extra result of this little episode has been a run on overtime to make up for the time and money lost during Senator Chaney's catastrophic last stand. Over three-quarters of the overtime budget of his Department has been spent in under two-thirds of the financial year. As we have been assured by the Minister and by the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) that overtime will not be cut out in his Department, it is probable that there will have to be additional appropriations for more overtime.

In putting thousands of unemployed single persons and sickness beneficiaries through the ordeal of having to ask for charity during these weeks because their cheques were not processed, Senator Chaney, his Department and his Government have caused considerable personal difficulties to people. He caused a considerable wastage of public funds-over $1m-that could have been put to far better use in staffing and in assistance to clients. The irony of it all is that at the end of the bans and then the lock-out, the Government admitted to the union that there was in fact a staffing problem, something which senior officers of the Department had always said and that reports to the Department had confirmed previously. Senator Chaney agreed to call in an outside consultant to review the Department's staffing. I suggest that this was something that could have been done before he called out the artillery which was at his disposal, before he wasted the taxpayers' money, before he caused the aid agencies considerable expenditure, before he caused the difficulties that were caused to the New South Wales Department of Youth and Community Services, and before he put beneficiaries and pensioners to a great deal of humiliation and anguish during the dispute.

In answers to myself and to Senator Bolkus and, on the Minister's behalf, by Mr Hunt to Mr Free in another place, we have the final summing up of just how futile this whole exercise was and just how costly it was in public funds. Unfortunately, we do not have a measure of how costly it was in personal anguish and difficulties to the various beneficiaries in the community. It is another example of the Minister and the Government forgetting that the Department of Social Security was set up to assist those who are disadvantaged and to assist those in need, and not to create more disadvantage and more need and anxiety for those who are in difficulty in the community. I am sure that when the Additional Estimates come out, Senator Mulvihill, myself and others who are on the relevant Estimates committee will have something further to say about this matter. We may even get finer details than we have from the questions on notice. But in the meantime the matter is on the record in the Senate. I hope that the Minister and the Government will learn from the futility of the exercise they conducted last year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not surprised that Senator Grimes should choose the dead of night when our proceedings are not being broadcast to put the record straight in the manner he has. I am sure the only people who will be aware that he has done it will be his few supporters in the union movement on whose behalf, no doubt, he spoke this evening. But I think it is fascinating that he can speak for some 10 minutes, chiding the Government for its behaviour during this strike, and let not a word escape his lips about the behaviour of a few silly extremists who did so much to try to harm pensioners and beneficiaries in this country. I think that is why the speech was made in the dead of night when we are not on the air.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is, of course, that it certainly was necessary to advertise during the course of that strike. One of the most unfortunate features of the strike was the misinformation put forward during its very early days. Greatly exaggerated claims of the extent of disruption were put abroad. It was highly desirable, in the interests of pensioners and beneficiaries, that the true position be made plain to them. Senator Grimes referred in his speech to the heading on a number of the advertisements: 'Message to Social Security Clients' and 'Message to Pensioners'. I make no apology at all for endeavouring to ensure that the people who are dependent upon the Department of Social Security were aware of the facts and not of some of the fictions which were flying about.

As far as any question of Public Service bashing is concerned, the fact of the matter is that from the time I have held this portfolio I have tried to make my concerns the concerns of those public servants who man my Department and who draw my attention and the attention of the senior management of the Department to what they see as deficiencies. I took up with the Government a number of matters raised by members of my Department. I refer to the additional funds that were obtained by me from the Government to upgrade office accommodation and the program of office accommodation upgrading which then ensued. I refer to the more than ample staff ceiling cover I obtained for the new functions which were required, which was a direct result of the view put forward that there had been inadequate provision for that in the past. I refer to the increased emphasis on training which was a response to the view expressed that there was inadequate training in the Department. I believe that during the course of 1981 there was ample evidence within the Department that there was a serious attempt to deal with all matters of administrative concern.

I at no stage claimed that everything in the Department was perfect. I made it quite explicit that in a department with 167 regional offices and nearly 12,500 staff members there would, of course, be points of difficulty, and I would expect to address myself to them. But the fact is that the great bulk of the loyal members of my Department stayed at work at all times. They stayed at work out of loyalty to their clients. In fact the great bulk of payments which were due to be made by my Department were made on time to the people who were supposed to get them. In only two States, New South Wales and Victoria, did a minority of people manage to disrupt payments at all. I very much regret the disruption which occurred and point to the action which we took to minimise the effect on clients.

I do not believe that the speech which has just been made in the Senate is even vaguely the speech of somebody who would purport to be part of the alternative government of this country. I am sorry the speech was made when it was because I believe that if it had been widely heard it would have been judged by the Australian people as a totally unsuitable speech. There is not a single word of complaint about the fact that, at one stage, a few unionists set out to stop a computer run of a quarter of a million cheques. They tried to prevent the payment of a quarter of a million cheques to age pensioners, sickness beneficiaries and so on, at the same time as they were publicly claiming that they were doing everything possible to help clients. A directive was issued in writing over the signature of a union official, saying that that run should not occur and not a word of chiding was heard in this place about that sort of behaviour.

At all times I also indicated that the position of the staffing of my Department is not and has not been static. A series of changes were made last year and I was more than prepared to examine areas of complaint. As soon as the dispute lifted, I met with the union as I had undertaken to do, and I discussed with it the way that review could be approached. An independent consultant has now been appointed in accordance with the view I expressed on 22 December, immediately following the dispute. I have little doubt that the review will produce information which will be of assistance to me, to the Government and to the management of the Department in doing our job well and properly.

I acknowledge the fact that the Department is dependent upon the loyal and devoted service of the people who work in it. I acknowledge also that the great bulk of them continue to give that loyal and devoted service to which I pay tribute, and I regret their efforts and the efforts of the Government to serve the people of Australia were interfered with in the way that they were. But there is no regret on my part that, during this dispute, the Government made the position clear to the union, to the people of Australia and to the pensioners and beneficiaries of this country. I believe that we did no more and no less than the people who elected us to govern would expect and, indeed, many of those who did not vote for us would have expected also.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make some comments in relation to certain parts of a speech made by Senator Gietzelt last Thursday in relation to the annual reports of 1980-81 for Trans Australia Airlines and Ansett Transport Industries Ltd. As reported in Hansard, Senator Gietzelt said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Trans Australia Airlines report sets forth all of the activities of that organisation . . .
He went on to talk about some of the detail. He then said:
It is in accordance with the requirements of the Act.

However, the report from Ansett Transport Industries Ltd is a four-page typewritten document which just sets out the financial situation of that organisation with a very short covering letter by the directors. That really is a very inadequate report from the private sector airline-which always claims to be more efficient and more able to present its case to the Australian public- than the report in respect of the Government owned airline.

Lest there should be any continuing misunderstanding as to the nature of the reporting obligations and the reports actually presented in respect of the two participants in Australia's two airlines agreement, I would like to clarify that the report to which Senator Gietzelt was referring so far as Trans Australia Airlines was concerned is the annual report which, under the legislation establishing the Australian National Airlines Commission, that airline is required to present to Parliament. That is its annual report in full detail. I join with Senator Gietzelt in saying that it is a good and complete compliance with the Commission's requirements under the Act.

However, Ansett Transport Industries was presenting an annual financial report to the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) relating to the operation of air services in pursuance of clause 11 of the 1972 two airlines agreement, which is an entirely different obligation. It is an obligation which arises as a result of an agreement entered into between the Government and the two major domestic airlines and does completely and fully comply with its obligations under that agreement. It extracts from its annual report, which is made under the Companies Act, all of the information which is separated and applicable to its airline operations, which enables a comparison to be made between the airline operations of TAA and the airline operations of Ansett Transport Industries. It is well known that both of them have activities other than operating an airline.

There are parts of the annual report of TAA which deal only with the airline operation. The document I have is provided to the Minister by Ansett and tabled for the information of the Parliament but the Ansett report to be compared with TAA's full report is the one which I will seek leave to table in a moment. It is Ansett Transport Industries Ltd's 44th annual report which is its full company report under the Companies Act which provides all of the information similar to the sort of information provided in the TAA report. I think that it would be unfortunate if that matter was not corrected for the record. I seek leave, therefore, to table the annual report which is the full report of Ansett Transport Industries.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Gietzelt went on to make certain other comparisons. Very briefly I would like to say that I think there are some points to be made in relation to the comparison between the success last year and in the past few years of the two airlines. Last year the operating profit before tax of TAA was $46,000; Ansett's was $27,327,000. The provision for tax by TAA was a net benefit of $168,000 whilst Ansett made provision to pay $14,988,000. This is not something which is a novelty arising out of any question of the Government's review of the structure of TAA. Over the past four years one can compare Ansett' s after tax profit of something in excess of $51m with TAA's of just over $15m and the income tax paid by Ansett of $54m with that of TAA at $2.4m. The figures of TAA do not take into account the $180m liability which has now, according to the last report, risen in some eight years in respect of the unfunded contributions to Commonwealth superannuation under which it has an obligation to make payments to the Government but has not made them.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that there are bases upon which we can say that, where the observer can see two apparently parallel and equally efficient airlines operating, both providing what I believe to be an excellent service-none of the comments that I make I would wish to be taken as attacking the operations of the airline services provided by Trans Australia Airlines-and where the figures vary as much as I have pointed out, questions arise as to structure and operation. It is legitimate for the Government as the shareholder in effect of the statutory authority to say: 'Let us review the operation'. The comparison is so extraordinary as to need some explanation. I do not pause tonight to endeavour to make any explanation. I do pause to thank the Minister for Transport for ensuring that TAA's reports which have always been prepared in good time but not always made available in good time by the Minister and his Department and Ansett 's obligation under the two-airline agreement have been made available to Parliament months earlier than has been the average over the past few years. As I have been one who has complained in the past about it, I would like to take the opportunity to acknowledge that that problem at least has been overcome. I thank the Senate for the opportunity to make those few remarks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take a very brief time to refer again to a matter I raised last Thursday on page 734 of Hansard in connection with the Grace Bros rip-off. I want to complete the record on that matter. There was quite an amazing response over the last few days. People were delighted to see that some truths were being told about that particular company. They showed that the matter I outlined on Thursday was not an isolated case. Almost the same situation happened to another family in Hobart who came from Canada last year. Their goods, furniture and so forth were shipped from Toronto across to the coast and then to Australia for $2,300. Grace Bros then charged more than $500 to take their effects from the Hobart wharf to its store in a Hobart suburb. There were quotes from other companies of less than half that amount but-this is the important point-because the goods were in a container in which there were other goods they could not get access to them in order to take advantage of the cheaper quotes. They were locked into a situation from which they could not escape. Grace Bros had their goods and were able to call the tune on the price and everything else.

SPEECH.PARA: I just wanted to report that a number of people added to the complaints about Grace Bros in response to my speech last week. There was another case, again involving the United Kingdom, where the company had been suggested by Tasmania House, which of course does not now exist. Its agents turned out to be Grace Bros. Once again there was no way of avoiding using the firm. I want to refer to the fact that this whole lack of choice, the blackmail involved, the grip on the overseas market by Grace Bros, strikes me as being a restrictive trade practice which I want to refer to the Trade Practices Commission and the Tasmanian Consumer Affairs Council. I am in the process of doing that. The only other point to mention to complete the story is that so far the company concerned has made absolutely no response whatsoever to my complaints.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was not my intention to speak tonight, but in view of Senator Peter Rae's remarks on what Senator Gietzelt had to say about the tabling of the financial report by Ansett Transport Industries Ltd-as he has pointed out this has to be done in compliance with clause 11 of the two airlines agreement-and about that report in comparison with Trans Australia Airlines, I make the remark that Senator Peter Rae is well known for his opposition to the Government airline in favour of the private airline. Perhaps in view of the fact that Senator Peter Rae has now tabled the full report of Ansett Transport Industries tonight, in future Ansett Transport Industries might see fit to table in the Parliament a full and comprehensive report of its financial operations as does TAA and then of course whoever speaks on the report for the Opposition may be able to make a true comparison.
—Including News Ltd.

—That is right. While Senator Peter Rae might have been correct when he said that Ansett Transport Industries did comply with section 11 of the two airlines agreement, if he wants to use that as an argument, as appears from what he said tonight when he sought leave to table the full financial report of Ansett Transport Industries-of course, no one objected-perhaps in the future he will talk to his colleagues and his friends at Ansett Transport Industries to see whether they too will make that report available to the Parliament at the same time as TAA tables its report so that we will have a full and comprehensive report from both airline companies. Whilst TAA may take some heed of what Senator Peter Rae said tonight, it too might in the future bring in a very abbreviated report and barely comply with clause 11 which I think he mentioned.
—No, they have a statutory obligation under the Act that set them up as a statutory authority. That was the point that was missed the other day, and you are missing it again tonight.

—It may have that. But whilst the company has to do it, we do get more information from TAA in the Parliament than we get from Ansett Transport Industries. As my colleague said, we could do with some information about News Ltd as well. I refer to Mr Murdoch. Perhaps in the future when the report comes in, we may see not the trade name of Ansett Transport Industries but the name Murdoch Airlines. Let us have a look at the whole of Murdoch's operations as against the operations of TAA. As I said, it is well known that Senator Peter Rae would like to see TAA disposed of. He has said that many times in the Senate, if not directly then by insinuation. He would like to see a monopoly airline operating in this country. I am sure that in that circumstance we would not be getting the service which we are getting at present. It is unfortunate that Senator Gietzelt is not here tonight. I do not know whether Senator Rae notified Senator Gietzelt.
—I did.
—He is not here so that is his fault. It is his responsibility. In my view if the honourable senator notified him he should have been here.
—I wish you wouldn't tell untruths in saying that I want a monopoly. I have always expressly said that that is not so. I said I wanted a restructuring.

—The honourable senator has insinuated that TAA is a non-profit organisation. He uses its superannuation scheme and all of these things to bolster his argument as to why it should not operate and why Ansett Transport Industries-or Murdoch Transport Industries, as it should rightfully be known, because Ansett does not have much say in it now; it is run by Murdoch-should be a monopoly airline. We would be in dire trouble in this country if that ever happened.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Mulvihill raised a matter which is concerning him about the application of Australia's refugee and special humanitarian programs in relation to Polish refugees-I think we could appropriately call them Polish asylum-seekers-in various parts of Europe. Overwhelmingly, Poles seeking asylum are concentrated in camps in Austria, where there are, on the latest figures that I have, nearly 23,000 Poles . There are elsewhere in Europe, of course, some Polish asylum-seekers- approximately 7,000 in the Federal Republic of Germany, only 750 in Italy and some 3,000 in other countries.
—That would include my French query, no doubt?

—Presumably yes. I do not have a specific figure on how many there are in France. The policy of the Australian Government, which was stated today in a full statement by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee), indicates that Australia's contribution to relieving this congestion in Europe of refugees from Poland is on a per capita basis higher than any other country. We have increased our global figure of refugees covered under our refugee and special humanitarian programs by 2,000 for the current financial year. That brings the global figure, I think, to a total of about 24,500. Out of that figure it is expected that there will be 4,400 Polish refugees. That is a significant proportion of our total global program.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not able to say exactly from what parts of Europe these 4,400 Polish refugees are coming. I do not think there is any particular quota for specific countries, but I will have that matter checked. The additional 2,000 refugees covered by our programs to help relieve congestion in Austria and Germany was brought about really as a result of those figures that I mentioned. There is an overwhelming concentration of refugees in Austria and Germany. That is not to say that there would not be Polish refugees from other parts of Europe seeking asylum in Australia who would be eligible for consideration. I will have to refer that matter specifically to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to see whether particular quotas have been put on other parts of Europe. I thought it was important that the Senate should know that overwhelmingly the refugees are concentrated in Austria and Germany.

As a matter of interest, despite what seems to be a very high figure, as I have just mentioned, of those seeking refugee status or asylum, it is estimated that something like 200,000 to 250,000 Poles are resident in western Europe at the moment. They are only temporarily residing in western Europe and are not in fact seeking refugee status. They are simply waiting in western Europe in the hope that the situation in Poland will improve sufficiently to enable or encourage them to return. At the moment those people are not seeking asylum anywhere in the world. The policy of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees is that they should not be encouraged to do so but that their future should be assessed as the situation in Poland unfolds. Many of these people are being allowed by western European countries to stay and work in those countries. The policy of these countries is to extend those sorts of conditions to them thus relieving what would be, of course, a tremendous additional increase in refugees from Poland and pressures on refugee programs such as our own.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.17 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 17 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have the M-61A1 20 mm Vulcan rotary cannon installed on the Royal Australian Air Force's F111C aircraft been removed; if so, why, and to what use is the space vacated being put.
(2) Are these cannon similar to the units to be installed in the RAAF's FA18 fighters.
(3) Are the cannon from the F111Cs compatible with Australia's FA18 aircraft; if so, will these weapons be used as spares for the FA18 program.
(4) Have the weapons aboard the F111C ever been fired in service; if not, why were they specified for the aircraft.
(5) Will these cannon be scrapped.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) and (3) Yes. Both aircraft types are equipped with the M-61A1 cannon. However, some components, such as mountings and ammunition feed mechanisms, are peculiar to each aircraft type. Common components could be used in either aircraft.
(4) Yes.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 17 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What would have been the cost at current exchange rates as at 30 November 1981 if the Panavia Tornado had been selected for the tactical fighter replacement program, on the same costing basis as the $2.43 billion figure provided in the statement of the Minister for Defence, dated 20 October 1981 for the McDonnel Douglas FA18.
(2) Would the Panavia aircraft have cost $400m less than the FA18, as reported in the November edition of Aircraft magazine.
(3) Could the Interdictor Strike version of the Tornado have replaced the F111C aircraft in the 1990's.
(4) What advantages would have accrued if the RAAF had been equipped with the two main versions of the Panavia Tornado as its major combat aircraft in the 1990's.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Panavia Tornado was dropped from Australian contentions in 1978 when the short-list was reduced from six to four. The Tornado was excluded from further evaluation principally because the capabilities it offered were not appropriate to the Australian environment even if a two variant solution, involving a mix of the Air Defence Variant (ADV) and the Interdiction/Strike ( IDS) variant, were pursued. The Defence Department's objective in reducing the New Tactical Fighter short-list to two contenders was to allow a comprehensive comparative assessment to be made of the real program costs of the contenders against Australian requirements in the Australian operating environment. This indepth comparative evaluation of operational capability, and support and life cycle costs, performed by a large team of operational, engineering support, industry and scientific specialists, could not have been done without restricting the short-list to two aircraft. Only a watching brief was kept on aircraft excluded from the competition in 1978 and 1979. Therefore, a data base equivalent to that used for the comparative evaluation of the F16 and FA18 aircraft is simply not available for the Tornado. It follows that, without mounting a new evaluation effort of the same magnitude as that conducted in 1980 -81, an equivalent project cost for the acquisition of Tornado cannot be provided.

(2) The report in the November edition of Aircraft magazine appears to be based on an approach made to the Australian Government in late 1981 by the Panavia marketing organisation. It has to be recognised that costings provided via commercial marketing groups are in no way comparable with the costing exercises undertaken by the Department of Defence which include, as well as the acquisition costs of the aircraft and its engines, the costs of configuration changes to meet unique RAAF operational requirements, and the cost of simulators , spares, test equipment, training equipment and the like. The Defence Department costs also include the cost of new buildings and overhaul facilities at RAAF Bases, the costs of establishing important support capabilities in Australian industry, and an allowance for contingencies. A first order estimation, based on the latest Panavia basic unit fly-away costs would indicate a project cost for the Tornado some four or five per cent more than for the FA18 . If anything, this estimate is conservative in that Panavia provided costs only for the IDS variant, of which 805 are being built. The RAAF would require a mixture of IDS and ADV types. The ADV is likely to be significantly more costly than the IDS because only 165 are being built.

(3) The IDS variant of the Tornado was designed for broadly the same role as the F-111C. However, the Tornado design was optimised for the European operating environment and, in comparison to the F111C, it has significantly less range and payload capability. Also, the Tornado does not have the system redundancy of the F111C, nor does it have a precision attack infra-red/laser system similar to the Pave Tack system currently being acquired for the F111C. Adoption of the Tornado for the RAAF strike role would involve a significant retrograde step from the operational capability of the F111C.

(4) No advantages of any operational or financial significance would accrue. In fact the contrary would be true. That is, even a two variant solution would not meet RAAF requirements in the Australian operating environment.
