QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 17 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of a public meeting to discuss possible terms for a Makarrata which was advertised in the Canberra Times on 26 August 1981 and held in Canberra on 27 August 1981.
(2) By what authority was it called and by whom was it financed.
(3) When has the Minister received proposals from the National Aboriginal Conference about the content of a proposed Treaty or Makarrata.

(4) Will the Minister guarantee that consideration of such a Treaty or Makarrata by the Government will not take place until an adequately funded program of Aboriginal discussion and debate has been conducted.
(5) Will the Government grant financial support at a level to enable Aboriginal political and community organisations to conduct such discussion and debate.

(6) Is the Minister aware of programs under which the Government of Canada finances similar political and community organisations amongst Indians and other ethnic groups; if so, will Australian Aboriginal organisations be funded to a similar level.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) The meeting was called by the New South Wales Branch (which includes the Australian Capital Territory) of the National Aboriginal Conference. It was held in conjunction with the New South Wales State Branch meeting in Canberra.

(3) The National Aboriginal Conference published an interim report after its initial round of consultations with Aboriginal and Islander communities on 2 July 1980. I received further proposals on 29 September and 1 October 1981.

(4) and (5) The Commonwealth Government has already responded to the initial report and is prepared to discuss the concept further when the National Aboriginal Conference wishes to have talks. The Government recognises that consultation with Aboriginal communities is an essential element in the development of the concept and is providing special assistance to the NAC for this purpose. An amount of $50,000 has been allocated for the purpose in 1981-82 .

(6) I am aware of the Canadian programs referred to. Comparable Aboriginal organisations have been given comparable assistance: The Land Councils in the Northern Territory, for example were established and funded to prepare submissions to Mr Justice Woodward on land rights issues and more recently the Pitjantjatjara Council was assisted to develop proposals and conduct negotiations with the South Australian Government on land issues.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 17 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories developed a serum for funnel-web spider bites; if so, is the anti-venom freely available for the treatment of funnel-web spider bites; if not, when is it expected that restrictions on the use of this serum will be eased.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Yes. The anti-venom is not freely available. It is currently being used in a clinical trial being conducted by Professor T. Torda and Dr M. Fisher of Sydney. Initially, supplies of the anti-venom were held at seven New South Wales hospitals. More recently, an additional two hospitals in New South Wales have received supplies.

Approval for the anti-venom to be freely available will require a recommendation to that effect by the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee, which must satisfy itself as to the anti-venom's quality, safety and efficacy.

Prior to the anti-venom's recent use in the clinical trial, there had been only limited testing in animals and no use in humans. It is thus necessary to collect sufficient information to permit the Committee to make a judgement. As the use of the anti-venom is infrequent (only three occasions in almost 18 months) it is difficult to say when sufficient information will be available to permit consideration by the Committee. This will be decided by the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories in consultation with the doctors conducting the trial and will depend in no small part upon the degree to which both beneficial and adverse effects are observed in each individual patient receiving the anti-venom during the initial period of the trial.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: National Trachoma and Eye Health Programme

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 17 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the National Trachoma and Eye Health Programme be abandoned or has a delay been brought about by the inability of the Royal Australian College of Ophthalmologists to decide how the program will be administered.
(2) Will the project be further delayed; if so, will Government funds already allocated for this financial year be withdrawn.
(3) What action if any will be taken to ensure that the program is resumed without any further delay.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1-3) The Government does not intend to abandon the provision of necessary ongoing eye care recommended by the National Trachoma and Eye Health Program. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 18 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: 1. Were permanent officers serving in the Australian defence forces up to February 1975, ineligible to qualify for Imperial long-service awards; if so, why.
2. Why was 14 February 1975 chosen as the date to which eligibility for the new Australian awards, replacing the Imperial awards, should be retrospective.

3. Why, in view of the great service given to the nation by regular officers who served with the defence forces during the period from 1945 to 1975, contributing immeasurably to the construction of our present-day defence structure, are they denied any award in recognition of their services, simply because they retired before 14 February 1975.
4. Will the government give recognition to those officers instead of discriminating against them because the period of their service ceased prior to 14 February 1975.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: 1. Yes. The Imperial system of honours and awards does not include any award for the recognition of long service by permanent officers of the armed forces.
2. 14 February 1975 was the date on which the Australian system of honours and awards was established.

3. Until 14 February 1975, permanent officers in the Defence Force had no expectation of receiving a long service award. Officers whose services ceased before that date have therefore not been denied an award which was available under the condition under which they served.

4. See 3 above. There is no unfair discrimination against those officers whose services ceased before 14 February 1975. It would be inappropriate to apply to them conditions which derive from a system of awards which did not come into operation until that date.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McIntosh Sen G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 23 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister been advised of details of an action carried out by the security forces of the Philippines against the village of Sag-Od, in which 45 inhabitants were killed, as part of a campaign against the fledgling New People Army.
(2) Did the incident take place near a massive Australian Aid Project to build roads in the Island of Samar.

(3) When Australia decided to spend $25 million on this Aid Project, did the Australian Government not discuss the project with the people of Samar but just accepted the Philippine Government's evaluation of the situation.
(4) Are the roads built by Australia in fact being used by the military to suppress the people of Samar.

(5) Is there opposition locally to this Australian Aid Project; if so, what will the Australian Government do to ensure that this Aid Project is not used to exploit the very people it was meant to assist.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Reports which my Department has received from our embassy in Manila do not, however, enable me to confirm or deny that the killing was an act of the security forces of the Philippines or that it was part of a specific campaign against the New People's Army.

(2) The incident occurred in the province of Northern Samar where the Australian Government is supporting a major integrated rural development project which includes much more than the building of roads, namely agricultural development, water supplies, rural electrification, telecommunications and training. In fact there are at present more Australian manhours put into agriculture than into roads. While project activities cover the whole province of Northern Samar the village of Sag-Od is almost on the border with Western Samar and in an area remote from any concentration of project activity.

(3) The formal request for Australian assistance with the development of Northern Samar, one of the most underdeveloped areas in the Philippines, came from the Government of the Philippines. This was in accordance with established procedures. Before deciding to participate in the project the Australian Government commissioned several studies including detailed pre-feasibility and feasibility studies. The latter lasted six months, was conducted in the province by Australian personnel and involved discussions with people of all levels.

(4) The military authorities cannot be said to be using roads built with Australian assistance to 'suppress the people of Samar'. The project has in fact built no new roads on the island. All it has done so far has been to upgrade one 6km stretch of existing road from the capital of the province (Catarman) to the next town. Roads whch are being upgraded are some distance from the major areas of military activity.

(5) I am aware that there is some local opposition to the project particularly from some church representatives. There is no evidence, however, that such opposition is widespread. The Bishop of Catarman and other church leaders, with whom Australian personnel maintain close contact, have commented favourably on the project. The views of church critics have not been taken lightly and our embassy in Manila and project personnel have endeavoured to maintain dialogue with them even though the critics have been reluctant to discuss their reservations directly. I might add that the project is constantly being redefined in the light of feedback from local authorities and people in the project area and that the regular dialogue with local church authorities plays an important role in this process.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 November 1981 Senator Chipp asked the Leader of the Government in the Senate, without notice (Hansard, page 2263):

ANSWER.PARA: I ask a question of the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Having regard to the defence risks to the people of Darwin, including the presence of B-52 bombers, the increasing noise pollution caused by the present location of Darwin Airport and the availability of suitable land to the south of the city, will the Government, before allocating additional funds for the upgrading of Darwin Airport, undertake an analysis of the economic and social advantages of relocating the airport to a less populated area and hold a public inquiry into the relationship between the future development of Darwin and its air transport needs?
The Minister for Transport has provided me with the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The issue of aerodrome relocation was considered by a broadly based working group following Cyclone Tracy. The group concluded that the high cost of relocation could not be justified by the possible benefits. There is no foreseen need for further analysis of this matter.
The honourable senator should note that I gave a similar reply to Senator Mason's question on notice, No. 1534, of 12 November 1981.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 February 1982 (Hansard, page 142) Senator Hearn asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. As it is now 11 years since Australia signed the United Nations Convention on psychotropic substances, why has the Federal Government not ratified that agreement?
The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Amendments to both State and Territory laws were required before Australia could ratify the conventions. These amendments have now been made and steps are currently being taken to enable Australia's formal ratification.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 February 1982 (Hansard, page 474) Senator Gietzelt asked me, as the Leader of the Government in the Senate, a question without notice regarding expenditure cutbacks in the government departments task force report on departmental information.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following in answer to the honourable senator's question:

I understand Senator Gietzelt is referring to the report of the Task Force on Departmental Information which was the subject of my recent press release a copy of which I am pleased to provide to Senator Gietzelt.

The report was completed in July 1980 and a copy is now available in the Parliamentary Library. The report has been the subject of the Government's consideration in the light of other related reviews including the Freedom of Information legislation.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Harbour Facilities at Yampi Sound and Cockatoo Island

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 February 1981 (Hansard, page 155) Senator Hamer asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is it a fact that Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd has offered to sell the Royal Australian Navy its harbour facilities at Yampi Sound and Cockatoo Island as patrol boat bases? If so, what price is being asked? If so, what price is being asked? Is there a need for an additional patrol boat base in this area? If so, what would be the cost of building from scratch a suitable base?
The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
The need for the Commonwealth actually to acquire a site for a possible future patrol boat base in the north-west was examined and resolved during mid to late 1981.

A review of available sites, including Cockatoo Island (BHP), has confirmed that a site at Finucane Island near Port Hedland would be preferred for any development of patrol boat facilities in the north-west.

The Prime Minister announced on 8 December 1981 that discussions have been held with Western Australia about the siting of naval facilities in the north- west. Programming of any facility would follow detailed examination of the facilities required.
Pending detailed examination and consideration of options and competing priorities within the Defence programme any statement on cost would be premature.

A first right of refusal for the Commonwealth to acquire the Finucane Island site has been negotiated and the Western Australian Department of Lands and Surveys has noted the Commonwealth's interest in the site on its plans.

This action safeguards for the Commonwealth the option to develop facilities at Port Hedland while permitting the consideration of any more suitable site which might arise in the light of any other port development in Western Australia.
